target_title: Make it easier for apps to withdraw notifications appropriately

note.body:
> Not everyone uses `gnome-shell` (I use `dunst` for notifications myself).

It doesn't matter what *you* use: what matters is that you cannot rely on a notification server providing support for timeouts, because it's an entirely optional functionality. Even if GLib provided that API, you'd be constrained to a specific (but unknown) subset of environments and notification servers.

target_title: Make it easier for apps to withdraw notifications appropriately

note.body:
Not everyone uses `gnome-shell` (I use `dunst` for notifications myself). Is `glib` limited to what GNOME supports or is it a library intended for use in wider contexts too? I mean, if GNOME wants to not-support timeouts on notifications, fine, but why make it so that GTK apps *can't* do it without "let's just sling integer handles around and hope things work out"[1] shenanigans or just foregoing `GNotification` and opting instead for continuing to use `libnotify` or (*shudder*) forking off to `notify-send` for this?

[1] Can `GSource` ids be reused? What threading machinations are involved between the `withdraw` timer and the `action` coming back from the notification daemon? Do I need a mutex on the `myid -> gsource_id` map?

target_title: Make it easier for apps to withdraw notifications appropriately

note.body:
You mean the [`expire_timeout` argument](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/notification-spec/latest/protocol.html#id-1.10.3.3.4) of `org.freedesktop.Notifications.Notify`? It’s [not used](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/blob/main/js/ui/notificationDaemon.js?ref_type=heads#L136) in gnome-shell, and neither is there an equivalent connected in [the `org.gtk.Notification` implementation](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/blob/main/js/ui/notificationDaemon.js?ref_type=heads#L413).

Even if GLib provided an API for it (and doing so would mean a lot of thought about whether it’s the right way to meet use cases), it wouldn’t work in gnome-shell.

target_title: Make it easier for apps to withdraw notifications appropriately

note.body:
Discussion seems to have stalled here. If anyone wants to take any of the ideas here further, my recommendation would be to propose additions to the fdo notifications spec, and put a link to that proposal here so others can CC themselves if they’re still interested.

There’s nothing we can do unilaterally in GLib.

GSubprocess will manually close all open fds except those you tell it not to close; gspawn won't do that for you. This almost certainly indicates a bug in your program (missing `O_CLOEXEC`), not a bug in gspawn. But if you think there really is a bug in gspawn, feel free to report an issue for that.

Just please don't add more comments about gspawn to this issue, because this is a GDBus issue report. It has nothing to do with gspawn.

target_title: Feature Request: Add g_signal_connect_after_swapped() to GSignal API

note.body: We would probably want to call it `g_signal_connect_full()` and accept a GConnectFlags argument (e.g. `G_CONNECT_AFTER | G_CONNECT_SWAPPED`), for extensibility. `g_signal_connect_after()` and `g_signal_connect_swapped()` were mistakes; function names aren't a great way to modify behavior because now we need a combinatorial number of new functions for each possible combination of options each time we want to add some new functionality.

target_title: Links crash application on MacOS due to lack of machine-id file

note.body:
If it's a Cocoa object and a pool exists, it's allocated in a pool. If it's a CoreFoundation object it's not.

The tricky part is that "and a pool exists". If you write a little test program that just includes Cocoa and creates a Cocoa object then there's no pool unless you create one. That would be the case for a glib unit test. But if you start a run loop--as Gtk does--then macOS creates a pool at the beginning of the iteration and drains it at the end. Threads do likewise.

So although I wasn't thinking that way yesterday when I wrote the commit message, the safest way to handle Cocoa memory is to always create a pool for the context you're going to be using Cocoa objects in so you have complete control of the object lifetimes.

target_title: Use autorelease pool to manage cocoa memory.

note.body:
We never had to release `urlspec->appURL`. Doing so is what caused the crash.

The magic is that NSURL is a Cocoa, i.e. Objective-C, object so it's reference counted and when it is allocated the runtime keeps a reference in an autorelease pool. The  Objective-C runtime creates one for the thread when the thread is launched and drains it when it cleans up the thread but that's hidden. I added an autorelease pool to the thread function so that it would be visible to our future selves and they won't worry about it leaking.

The item urls are allocated with a CoreFoundation, i.e. C, function that doesn't do the autorelease pool magic so they need to be explicitly released.

Requirement of GUnixMountMonitor for a Valid Timestamp from unix_mount_at is not Suffeciently Documented

note.body:
For the timestamp returned by `Gio.unix_mount_at()` to be valid, you have to have a `GUnixMountMonitor` running. This is because `/proc/self/mountinfo` doesn’t have a valid mtime.

So you should find that if you start your script with `monitor = Gio.UnixMountMonitor.get()` then the timestamps work. Even better, this should also mean you can use the signals from `GUnixMountMonitor` to detect mount entry changes, rather than having to poll.

The documentation could be improved to mention this. I’ll put together a merge request.

note.body:
> So to find the other root cause I have to figure out what is the code for that thread, find the pointer that isn't initialized, and initialize it to NULL.

If you could do that, that would be incredibly helpful.

As a reminder, I don’t have any access to a macOS system, so this is not something I can investigate and fix myself.

> But that wouldn't be a terribly useful fix because it leaves GApplication operating on the false premise that there's always a dbus to talk to. We need a HAVE_DBUS flag and GApplication needs to behave reasonably when it's false.

It’s a necessary first step in a fix. GApplication defaults to using D-Bus, because that’s what it’s built on Linux, and for better or worse it was written (and is primarily maintained) by people on Linux. It is built around supporting alternative implementations for things, though, and #3403 was supposed to enable one of those for opening links. Somehow that’s not working here — so once the crash is fixed, that should give space for working out why #3403 is not working in this situation.

target_title: Links crash application on MacOS due to lack of machine-id file

note.body:
> something could be wrong with a D-Bus call somewhere

As reminder, starting with the fact that dbus isn't present by default on either macOS or Windows. The problem begins with GApplication expecting that it is. 

The debugger for LLVM is called lldb and that's what's shipped with Apple's development tools. Gdb works too, you just have to install it from Homebrew or MacPorts... or build it yourself. lldb is a fine debugger, in some ways better than gdb, so there's not much point.

Anyway, yes of course I can--and have--run gtk4-demo in the debugger. Simply back-tracing the crash didn't get me anywhere.

The crash is a side effect: The thread is done and is cleaning up its memory by releasing its memory pool, and there's an uninitialized pointer in that memory pool, freeing of which produces a segfault. At the point of the crash the name of the uninitialized variable is already lost.

So to find the other root cause I have to figure out what is the code for that thread, find the pointer that isn't initialized, and initialize it to NULL. But that wouldn't be a terribly useful fix because it leaves GApplication operating on the false premise that there's always a dbus to talk to. We need a HAVE_DBUS flag and GApplication needs to behave reasonably when it's false.

target_title: gbytes: Squash data to `NULL` if length is zero

note.body:
> Problem is, this conflicts with the documentation of g_bytes_get_data(), which is very clear that 0 length could mean data is NULL _or_ it could mean it is an empty string (i.e. a non-null pointer that points to one nul byte). Now you've prevented that.

My changes here don’t conflict with the documentation for `g_bytes_get_data()`: they match the part of it which says that it could return `NULL`.

> Again, I think your approach here is probably for the best, but we should update the documentation of `g_bytes_get_data()` now.

I’m hesitant to change the documentation for `g_bytes_get_data()`, or the other constructors, because that would be a behaviour change. Currently, you can use `g_bytes_new_from_bytes()` to take a slice of a string, and the `data` pointer will be valid and available for use in pointer arithmetic. If we change it so `g_bytes_get_data()` returns `NULL` in that case, that breaks pointer arithmetic possibilities with substrings.

I don’t know if this is actually used in the wild, but it’s what I assume this part of the API was designed for initially, and hence why `g_bytes_get_data()` allows for that.

So I’d prefer to keep this MR as it is — restoring the behaviour from prior to !4290, but not changing API.

target_title: gbytes: Squash data to `NULL` if length is zero

target_title: Infinite loop in g_hash_table_lookup_node()

note.body:
So the assertion I want to add is really "iterate through every hash table bucket and confirm it is either occupied or tombstoned" which is a O(n) operation. We obviously cannot do that in release builds. But it's not actually useful to do this assertion in debug builds, because this is an extraordinarily rare problem that is extremely unlikely to be encountered when using a developer build.

What we could do instead is assert if the loop in `g_hash_table_lookup_node()` is iterated too many times. I'm not sure how to do that, though.

target_title: gbytes: Squash data to `NULL` if length is zero

note.body: The other problem is there are actually three separate constructors, which should behave consistently: `g_bytes_new()`, `g_bytes_new_with_free_func()`, and `g_bytes_new_from_bytes()`. I guess we probably don't need to touch `g_bytes_new_from_bytes()` since it will behave according to whatever `g_bytes_get_data()` returns. `g_bytes_new()` never allowed non-null zero-size data because of the use of `g_memdup2()`. But `g_bytes_new_with_free_func()` does allow this. That's really weird; we should change one or the other to be consistent.

target_title: gbytes: Squash data to `NULL` if length is zero

note.body:
I think your approach here is probably best because it reduces the risk of confusion.

This is basically the opposite of what I was trying to do. Problem is, this conflicts with the documentation of g_bytes_get_data(), which is very clear that 0 length could mean data is NULL _or_ it could mean it is an empty string (i.e. a non-null pointer that points to one nul byte). Now you've prevented that.

Again, I think your approach here is probably for the best, but we should update the documentation of `g_bytes_get_data()` now.

note.body:
If there are no objections I'd prefer to use `static inline` :slight_smile:  The problem with inline alone is that it's easy to get into ODR violations. There are mostly two ways that can happen:

1. The definition varies between object files for [hidden reasons](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/performance-diagnostics/deep-dive-analysis-why-did-this-dll-increase-in-file-size-by-50/)
2. We update the functions between GLib releases. With static libraries it can happen that both the older and the newer versions are present

target_title: gio mount -l not listing luks encrypted disks

note.body:
If you wanted to expand `GUnixVolumeMonitor` to support listing all volumes/drives/mounts, I think you’d need to do the following:
 * Add a boolean property to `GVolumeMonitor` called `show-uninteresting`, with a default value of false
 * Implement that property in `GUnixVolumeMonitor`
 * Factor the check for `!g_unix_mount_entry_guess_should_display (mount_entry)` out of `_g_unix_mount_new()` and instead do that check in the functions which call `_g_unix_mount_new()`
 * Then change that check to be skipped if the `GUnixVolumeMonitor:show-uninteresting` property is true
 * Add an option to `gio mount` (in `gio-tool-mount.c`) called `--show-uninteresting`, which would set the `GVolumeMonitor:show-uninteresting` property on `global_volume_monitor`
 * Check that other bits of code which call `g_unix_mount_entry_guess_should_display()` or `_g_unix_mount_new()` don’t need to be amended
 * Amend documentation throughout to mention the new behaviours, options and APIs. In particular:
   - Command line documentation for `gio mount` (in `docs/reference/gio/gio.rst`)
   - API documentation for `GVolumeMonitor`
   - Any internal documentation in `gunixmount.c` and `GUnixVolumeMonitor`
   - In particular, the API documentation for `GVolumeMonitor:show-uninteresting` needs to highlight that changing that property value will affect *all* users of the volume monitor singleton, and hence it must only be changed by top-level process code, not library code. See the documentation for `g_log_set_writer_func()` for an example of the wording to use.
 * Add relevant unit tests for the new functionality:
   - A test in `gio-tool.py` which checks that at least one mount is listed when running `gio mount -l --show-uninteresting`
   - Tests for the new property in `gio/tests/volumemonitor.c`

I’d be happy to review a merge request which does this, but don’t have time to implement it myself.

target_title: g_filename_from_uri rejects valid host names according to RFC 1123

note.body:
I'm coming here from a bug in [Terminator](https://github.com/gnome-terminator/terminator/issues/966), [Tilix](https://github.com/gnunn1/tilix/issues/2244), [Xfce Terminal](https://gitlab.xfce.org/apps/xfce4-terminal/-/issues/345), GNOME Console, GNOME Terminal, Ptyxis, Black Box, and perhaps some more GLib-based (VTE-based) terminal emulators.

A certain escape sequence lets the shell tell the current working directory to the terminal emulator, technically in the form of a URI. The terminal emulator can then open new tabs or windows in that directory, a nice convenience feature. If they use the obvious `g_filename_from_uri()` to extract the path then this fails if the hostname starts with a digit, causing this feature not to work on such hosts (or more severe faulty behavior in the 3 linked cases, but that's clearly the fault of those terminals).

With the suggested looser interpretation, i.e. allowing leading digits, such use cases would work, and anyone who needs the stricter check (disallow leading digits) could do that in a 1 line followup check on the returned hostname.

With the current stricter interpretation, i.e. disallowing leading digits, anyone who wishes to have the looser interpretation (allowing leading digits) would have to throw this method out of the window and find a different parser, or implement it from scratch.

That is, with practicality in mind, the suggested looser variant would be significantly more usable. I'd appreciate if you guys could please move forward with the suggested change. Thanks!

I intend on taking another look at this, probably over the xmas break.

My motivation is that I want to have

    double g_unicode_number_value (gunichar c)

which would return 0.75 for ¾ and 10.000.000.000 for U+16B60 PAHAWH HMONG NUMBER TEN BILLIONS.

target_title: Proposal:  Introduce a g_filename Typedef to Enhance Safety and Readability

note.body:
This approach doesn’t need to be limited to filenames. This should be done indeed for all different representations of strings. For example, in C23, there will be char8_t, a typedef for unsigned char, which represents UTF-8 strings. Unlike in C++, casting between char* and char8_t* in C doesn’t introduce undefined behavior, so it provides a better foundation for distinguishing UTF8 from other string encodings.

But the ideal solution would likely be to introduce a string-like struct for each encoding, containing at least a char* pointer. This would make it clear what encoding or format a string uses, but keeps the underlying char type. However, I didn’t propose this because it would be a very significant change. Adopting a Rust- or C++-like string class in GLib would essentially require rewriting a large portion of the library and its usage.

The reason I focused specifically on filenames is that they are particularly problematic as an "encoding." Filenames almost always require special handling:

 - On Windows, filenames are not directly usable for file I/O and need to be converted into the system’s narrow or wide string encoding. However, keeping them in UTF-8 at least allows them to be written to files or displayed in the console.
 - On UNIX, filenames are usable for file I/O, but re-serializing them requires special care.
 - Neither g_file nor filenames in general are straightforward to use, especially on Windows, where interoperability with external libraries (like the C++ STL, or C libraries expecting wchar_t strings) can be cumbersome.

target_title: Revert "gdbus: Fix leak of method invocation when registering an object with closures"

note.body:
> `g_dbus_connection_register_object_with_closures()` OTOH takes `GClosure`s for the different callbacks. `GClosure`s _never_ take any argument as `transfer full`, and the unit test was checking for broken behaviour in that regard which I fixed by having different ownership transfer semantics for the `GClosure` and non-`GClosure` variant of the test.

I think this is the crux of the issue, and I see where you’re coming from. I think it semantically comes down to whether you expect `GClosure` to mirror the refcounting semantics of the function it’s wrapping, or to impose its own (everything is `(transfer none)` and lifetimes are handled by the closure).

I don’t know what the right answer is for the future, but I do know that the change we merged in GLib has broken things in the 2.82.x stable series, when used in combination with released versions of pygobject, and that definitely needs reverting — even if we go with a different solution on `main` in the end.

>> Or said differently, if you revert this change please document that this API does not follow the ownership semantics of `GClosure` and mark it as `(skip)` because bindings can't be autogenerated for it and need special manual treatment.
> 
> Honestly, this sounds like a job for a new `g_dbus_connection_register_object_with_closures2()` (someone think of a better name, please?) that _does_ do what bindings want, designed by a binding author to be trivially bindable (even if the result is a somewhat unpleasant C API).

Perhaps, yeah. There’s nothing in the [original bug](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=656325) about adding `g_dbus_connection_register_object_with_closures()` where anyone mentioned the `(transfer full)` behaviour with closures, so it looks like an oversight rather than deliberate. 

It would be interesting to get @ptomato’s input on this, as he’s recently added a (different) closures API for bindings, in commit 64b06c633ae152b10ef7453d8068951af077280b.

target_title: Revert "gdbus: Fix leak of method invocation when registering an object with closures"

note.body:
That's exactly what `g_dbus_connection_register_object_with_closures()` was supposed to be though and why it was added (see commit message of 5d014a802a4b47fbf5774f613d61b4218a1aa2a2). It just had a refcounting bug, which was then also found by bindings (e.g. [here](https://github.com/dasbus-project/dasbus/pull/81/commits/eb075c6c9dbca53aeaabc311322d28183dd3c63d#r803891538)).

I think the main problem at this point is that https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/2600#note_1385050 effectively decided that the current behaviour is correct and not a bug, and the Python bindings added a workaround for this as a result.

The best is probably to revert this, document the API is broken, and then someone could add a `g_dbus_connection_register_object_with_closures2()` that does the refcounting correctly and otherwise doesn't do anything differently.

I'm fine with working around this in the Rust bindings the same way as the Python bindings do already, but this at least needs to be documented then so that not every other binding first has a memory leak until manual handling of the refcounting is added as a workaround for this case.

target_title: Revert "gdbus: Fix leak of method invocation when registering an object with closures"

target_title: Revert "gdbus: Fix leak of method invocation when registering an object with closures"

note.body:
Are we talking about `g_dbus_connection_register_object()` or `g_dbus_connection_register_object_with_closures()`? The former did not change at all, and everything you say is correct for that one. `GDBusInterfaceMethodCallFunc` is only involved in the public API of that one, not of the second one.

`g_dbus_connection_register_object_with_closures()` OTOH takes `GClosure`s for the different callbacks. `GClosure`s *never* take any argument as `transfer full`, and the unit test was checking for broken behaviour in that regard which I fixed by having different ownership transfer semantics for the `GClosure` and non-`GClosure` variant of the test.

> Where else adds that reference?

Bindings would do that when calling `g_dbus_method_invocation_return_*()` unless they have a concept of move semantics that allow them to pass off the reference. Exactly like how they do the same thing for literally any other function with `transfer full` parameters.

target_title: Revert "gdbus: Fix leak of method invocation when registering an object with closures"

note.body:
Or, to look at it from another angle: the GLib unit tests didn’t have any leaks before !4415 landed, but !4415 needed to add a `g_object_ref()` into the unit tests to keep them working. That means there’s been an API break in the refcounting behaviour.

(I totally should have caught that in code review, sorry.)

target_title: Revert "gdbus: Fix leak of method invocation when registering an object with closures"

note.body:
Regardless of whether the registration uses closures or not-closures, the user’s code is going to call `g_dbus_method_invocation_return_*()` exactly once on the invocation, and that’s going to consume a reference.

GLib adds one extra reference right before it calls the `GDBusInterfaceMethodCallFunc`. Closure support is implemented by providing a `GDBusInterfaceMethodCallFunc` wrapper around the closure. If that wrapper uses `g_value_take_object()` to consume a reference to the invocation, an extra reference needs to be added somewhere else to balance the one already guaranteed to be consumed by `g_dbus_method_invocation_return_*()`. Where else adds that reference?

target_title: Revert "gdbus: Fix leak of method invocation when registering an object with closures"

note.body:
I don't think this is correct. The normal callback (`GDBusInterfaceMethodCallFunc`) gets the invocation as `transfer full`, so for that you're right. That didn't change here. However `GClosure` (and signal handlers) *never* take any arguments as `transfer full` but they're only passed in `transfer none`.

The change to the Python bindings seems to be wrong, and working around the original leak that I fixed.

What am I missing?

----

`g_dbus_method_invocation_return_*()` take the invocation as `transfer full` but that's unrelated.

2.82.3 regression: lollypop crashes on startup

note.body:
It’s potentially something to do with the funky refcounting behaviour of `GDBusMethodInvocation`: a reference to the invocation is `(transfer full)` into the `GDBusInterfaceMethodCallFunc`, but the `g_dbus_method_invocation_return_*()` methods then take ownership of the `GDBusMethodInvocation` when it’s passed to them. That behaviour was changed for closures in !4417, and bindings might be using closures. They also might have previously had some code to work around the old refcounting behaviour. Coupled with the changes in !4417 that would lead to a double-unref and hence memory corruption.

I got part way through investigating this before I had to go out, and so far I have found https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pygobject/-/blob/main/gi/overrides/Gio.py?ref_type=heads#L147

I’ll keep looking.

target_title: Infinite loop in g_hash_table_lookup_node()

note.body:
I've started running flatpak-portal under valgrind and will leave it going today. It's extremely unlikely that I'll reproduce the broken hash table infinite loop ever again, but maybe if I'm lucky it will catch memory corruption somewhere. Probably not, but maybe.

At any rate, even if we don't know what went wrong, we can at least detect it. I'm tempted to add an assert to crash the process instead of infinite loop.

note.body:
This is surely memory corruption. Running python under `valgrind --track-origins=yes` should reveal what's wrong here. I assume your backtrace is pointing to innocent code, and there is some refcounting error on the GDBusMethodInvocation.

Fortunately, a reproducible crash is the best-case scenario for memory corruption. Reproducible means we can actually fix it. :)

target_title: Add nullable annotation for properties
Add nullable annotation for properties

note.body:
> At most, we could consider adding a `(not nullable)` annotation for properties that cannot be `NULL`, but that's generally a bad idea, because it's perfectly fine (and an established pattern) to use `NULL` as a sentinel value.

I think we should (eventually) support `(not nullable)` annotations for properties, but I agree that the default is `(nullable)` and should be marked as such by the scanner.

Not-nullable properties are possible in third-party code if you:
 * Provide a non-`NULL` default value in the `constructed` vfunc; and
 * emit a critical warning if `set_property` is called with `NULL` for the property.

Sure, the enforcement of that isn’t happening inside libgobject, but the non-nullability is still part of the external semantics of that API as documented and exposed by that third-party code.

target_title: GWin32: Add g_win32_com_clear()

note.body:
> The semantics were updated, and hence the name is updated: This releases the COM object and checks its refcount. This only resets the pointer to `NULL` when the refcount reaches 0. COM does not normally provide a way to check the refcount unless one calls `->AddRef()` or `->Release()` on the COM object.

That won’t match the behaviour of other `g_clear_*()` functions at all. People are going to be surprised by it. It doesn’t match the concept of ownership which GLib uses: if you have a variable with a strong reference to an object (whether a COM object or a GObject), once you’ve dereffed the object, you can’t guarantee other references to it will still exist — so your variable has to be cleared to `NULL`. Even if the object is still referenced from elsewhere.

e.g. What happens with `g_win32_release_com()` when two nested functions have references to the same COM object. One of the functions calls `g_win32_release_com()` and the COM object’s refcount falls from 2 to 1, so that function’s variable is not cleared to `NULL`. Then the other function calls it, the refcount falls from 1 to 0, and the second function’s variable is cleared to `NULL`. The first function’s variable is now a non-`NULL` point pointing to a fully released COM object which is presumably going to cause a use-after-free error if ever dereferenced or accessed.

What was the motivation for changing the proposed behaviour like this?

note.body:
Hi @pwithnall,

Sorry, I didn't get back to this until lately, so here are the changes that were made:

* The semantics were updated, and hence the name is updated: This releases the COM object and checks its refcount. This only resets the pointer to `NULL` when the refcount reaches 0.  COM does not normally provide a way to check the refcount unless one calls `->AddRef()` or `->Release()` on the COM object.
* Added C and C++ tests in `win32.c` and `cxx.cpp` respectively for this.
* Adapted docs as suggested and added notes about C4133 warnings one must bear with for Visual Studio C builds for now when using this.
* I will look at "And add a test to check that an expression with side-effects is indeed only evaluated once by `g_win32_com_clear()`" tomorrow, if needed.

With blessings, thank you!

Add nullable annotation for properties

note.body: Another thing we could do is to fix the introspection scanner to always emit `nullable` to pointer-sized properties; if that's enough, we should move this issue to gobject-introspection, since GLib only cares about the GIR → typelib compilation, these days.

target_title: Add nullable annotation for properties

note.body:
> For example: in C# and Vala it is possible to have nullable properties and also offer strict nullability checks. If a property returns NULL, while it is not annoted in the API, then it will cause runtime errors.

This is something that happens at the bindings level, not at the introspection level.

> Currently it is not possible to add `nullable` annotation to properties itself.

GObject properties that take a pointer-sized value (string, boxed, object, pointer) are **always** nullable by default, because:

1. the corresponding `GParamSpec` allows a nullable default value (`GParamSpecString`) or does not have a default value to begin with
2. constructor properties will be set to a default value if they are not passed to `g_object_new()`, and that default value is `NULL`

GObject cannot have a "non-nullable" property, with a subclass doing something inside `GObjectClass.constructed` or in the set/get property implementation; and even there, `NULL` is an expected value.

tl;dr: since `NULL` is a valid value, you must always consider all pointer-sized properties as nullable by default.

At most, we could consider adding a `(not nullable)` annotation for properties that cannot be `NULL`, but that's generally a bad idea, because it's perfectly fine (and an established pattern) to use `NULL` as a sentinel value.

Proposal:  Introduce a g_filename Typedef to Enhance Safety and Readability

note.body:
You could add something like:
```
#if ((defined (__STDC_VERSION__) && __STDC_VERSION__ >= 202311L) || 
defined(__cplusplus)) && GLIB_ENABLE_FILENAME_STRICT_TYPE_ALIAS != 0
  enum g_filename: char {GLIB_GFN_IGNORE_EMPTY};
#else
  typedef gchar g_filename;
#endif
```

This won't break the API unless the user want's this. Since both versions are already ABI compatible, one can just switch between those two versions, without recompiling glib.
With my knowledge, C++ will only have problems regarding aliasing. C++ will handle pointers to `gchar` and `g_filename`(the enum, not the typedef) as distinct memory regions, just like the restrict keyword is added to two `char*` parameters. This assumption is lifted at the moment, when
the enum is casted to a `gchar*`.
I can't tell, whether this will break introspection or not. Glib and GTK itself are unaffected by this.

target_title: Proposal:  Introduce a g_filename Typedef to Enhance Safety and Readability

note.body:
This is an interesting idea, but due to GLib’s API stability guarantees, it’s only going to be possible if:
 * It doesn’t break API (not breaking ABI is insufficient)
 * Particularly when being consumed by C++ users, where type checking is stricter
 * It doesn’t break introspection (since introspection depends on type matching)

target_title: Proposal:  Introduce a g_filename Typedef to Enhance Safety and Readability

note.body:
- The interesting thing is, that this wouldn't break ABI, because `gchar` and `enum : gchar` are link compatible.
- It won't break correct code during compilation of glib and dependencies, when you just disable the usage of the enum during compilation / by default.
- Library users can enable it, when they want, even when glib is compiled with using `gchar` as `g_filename`.

target_title: Proposal:  Introduce a g_filename Typedef to Enhance Safety and Readability

note.body:
You should read the discussion in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/merge_requests/3574

"Abandon glib atomic operations" is not a thing that can happen, as long as toolchains are not uniformly implementing C11, and we cannot remove API from GLib either.

If you want to use `stdatomic.h` for your application, you don't need GLib to give you an API for it.

Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body: `.shebang()` does not need a `native: true` kwarg, because `find_program()` already handles that for us. For the specific case of python via `find_installation()`, that needs some work, I think. It currently assumes you want to target the host machine.

target_title: Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body:
Something like: 

```
prog = find_program('some-interpreter')
cdata = configuration_data()
cdata.set('SHEBANG', prog.shebang(single_arg))
configure_file(
  input: 'script.ext.in',
  output: 'script.ext',
  configuration_data: cdata
)
```

Where `script.ext.in` is

```
#!@SHEBANG@

[rest of the script]
```

target_title: Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body:
Overall, if your interpreter entry in the machine file (whether `python3` or something else) is a command with arguments
 - The shebang cannot start with `/usr/bin/env`, it must be `#!@INTERPRETER@ @ARGS@`
 - The path to the command `@INTERPRETER@` cannot contain spaces
 - `@ARGS@` will be interpreted as a single argument, so it can contain spaces but not multiple args separated by spaces

I think this stuff is too arcane for each project to handle. Meson should have a feature to generate a shebang line, and error out if it can't (or find a workaround, like using a wrapper).

target_title: Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body: I think `runpython` thing is an issue with the meson installer. It should provide a separate executable `meson_runpython.exe`. Since the runpython thing exists only for Windows, unfortunately there is no way to use `meson runpython` as a shebang.

target_title: date_time_new_from_unix_local causes a memory leak

note.body:
For avoidance of doubt, `g_return_if_fail()` is an assertion that the statement will never fail. If it ever actually returns, then the program is invalid and further behavior is undefined, so cleaning up memory is not at all important and it's conventionally not performed. (Personally I think these functions are bad and they should all be replaced with `g_assert()` , but most developers disagree with me.)

If you want to make GLib robust to invalid timezone database files, then you should make sure it never fails any `g_return_if_fail()` tests. But honestly I agree that it's best to just not attempt this. I'd rather hit the `g_return_if_fail()`s and print criticals so the user knows that the system is broken. Alternatively, we could crash with a descriptive error message by using `g_error()`.

Notably, I think the FIXME comment is intended to indicate that we should add more `g_return_if_fail()` paths, not that we should gracefully support broken tdbz files.

`/* FIXME: Handle invalid TZif files better (Issue#1088).  */`

target_title: gio copy -p fails to report progress when source and destination are mounted NFS shares

note.body:
> I would guess that this goes thru `copy_file_range_with_progress` which as per the comment uses 2GB chunks: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/2b155f86dda3bf35cc13ec39977e1729e6b9a07a/gio/gfile.c#L3115-3118. This is maybe ok for local filesystem, but not for nfs/cifs...

That’s a pain. We want to use `copy_file_range()` for NFS in particular, because it allows the use of server-side copying. On local file systems it allows use of reflinks, but presumably only if the full file is copied. The code currently tries to use the full file size, but falls back to subsets of that if `copy_file_range()` returns early. The kernel may force it to at most 2GB chunks.

The more iterations we do, the more network round trips need to be done, and the less effectively the server-side copying works. But I can’t think of a way to report progress without doing more iterations, as the kernel provides no progress callback.

target_title: gio copy -p fails to report progress when source and destination are mounted NFS shares

target_title: Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body:
Thanks for looking back through the history, @danyeaw.

I was all ready to submit a comment saying I thought that from the discussion it sounded like `/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@`, where `@PYTHON@` is `python.full_path()`, was the right solution which would satisfy everyone, but actually that doesn’t fix #3331 because `python.full_path()` ends up being `/path/to/meson.exe` without the `runpython` argument.

It’s almost there though, it satisfies the requirements that I think people have (please say if I’ve missed one):
 - Works when the Python executable path contains spaces
 - Works with a relative executable path
 - Works with an absolute executable path (even if the `/usr/bin/env` prefix is completely redundant in that case)
 - Allows the Python interpreter to be overridden by a Meson machine file for cross-compilation

So perhaps we need to find another way to format the `python` object’s full argument list into `@PYTHON@` so we end up with `/usr/bin/env /path/to/meson.exe runpython` in those situations? And we end up with `@PYTHON@` being `python3` in most other (non-Windows, non-cross) situations? And we keep `/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@` consistent across all the Python files and only make the logic for determining `@PYTHON@` in `meson.build` a little more complex.

Separately, would it help if we explicitly prefixed all build-time invocations of the Python programs with the Python interpreter chosen by Meson? That would ensure they’re run under the interpreter specified in the machine file when cross-compiling on the build machine, but could still have a shebang which would work when run on the host machine (rather than the build machine).

> The memory should be released correctly when the program crashes.

No, we don't do that anywhere.

The OS is perfectly capable of cleaning up the memory by itself, and anything that follows a critical warning or an invalid case is by definition undefined behaviour.

> I think this is to improve the robustness of glib.

It would most definitely not do that.

date_time_new_from_unix_local causes a memory leak

note.body:
Sorry, no. The bug here is that somehow your system has been installed with one or more incorrect timezone database files. They’re a fundamental part of a working system, and almost everything relies on them. If we write code in GLib to handle these files being incorrect, that code will never be tested, and hence will be full of bugs, so might as well not exist. The fix here is for your distro or system administrator to make sure your timezone database files are correct.

This is just the same as if a library binary is missing. You don’t expect a program which depends on it to work around the issue and carry on working. It’s going to abort or crash.

target_title: date_time_new_from_unix_local causes a memory leak

note.body:
This part of the code is not much different from the 2.72.2 version. This is my patch based on the 2.72.2 version.

```shell
From 38974ffccb6c900e3dd60a1eb1573387fab3e632 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: renchunhui <chunhui_r@foxmail.com>
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2024 15:42:29 +0800
Subject: [PATCH] fix memory leaks.

---
 glib/gmessages.h      |    43 +
 glib/gtimezone.c      |    11 +-
 2 files changed, 49 insertions(+), 5 deletions(-)

diff --git a/glib/gmessages.h b/glib/gmessages.h
index c7efd53..dcbb541 100644
--- a/glib/gmessages.h
+++ b/glib/gmessages.h
@@ -586,6 +586,36 @@ GPrintFunc      g_set_printerr_handler  (GPrintFunc      func);
 #define g_return_if_fail(expr) G_STMT_START{ (void)0; }G_STMT_END
 
 /**
+ * g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier:
+ * @expr: the expression to check
+ * @identifier: the memory to free if @expr is not true
+ *
+ * Verifies that the expression @expr, usually representing a precondition,
+ * evaluates to %TRUE. If it evaluates to %FALSE, the function will log
+ * a critical message, free the memory pointed to by @identifier, and return
+ * from the current function.
+ *
+ * This macro is useful in scenarios where memory needs to be released before
+ * exiting a function due to an invalid precondition.
+ *
+ * If `G_DISABLE_CHECKS` is defined, the check is not performed. The memory
+ * pointed to by @identifier will not be freed, and the function will continue
+ * execution.
+ *
+ * Note: If the function does not need to release memory upon failure, use
+ * g_return_if_fail() or g_return_val_if_fail() instead.
+ *
+ * Example usage:
+ * 
+ * ```c
+ * g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier(ptr != NULL, my_allocated_mem);
+ * ```
+ *
+ * To debug failures of this check, see the documentation for g_return_if_fail().
+ */
+#define g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier(expr, identifier) G_STMT_START { (void)0; } G_STMT_END
+
+/**
  * g_return_val_if_fail:
  * @expr: the expression to check
  * @val: the value to return from the current function
@@ -646,6 +676,19 @@ GPrintFunc      g_set_printerr_handler  (GPrintFunc      func);
       } \
   } G_STMT_END
 
+#define g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier(expr, identifier) \
+  G_STMT_START { \
+    if (G_LIKELY (expr)) { \
+      { } \
+    } else { \
+      g_return_if_fail_warning(G_LOG_DOMAIN, \
+                               G_STRFUNC, \
+                               #expr); \
+      g_free(identifier); /* Free identifier if the expression fails */ \
+      return; \
+    } \
+  } G_STMT_END
+
 #define g_return_val_if_fail(expr, val) \
   G_STMT_START { \
     if (G_LIKELY (expr)) \
diff --git a/glib/gtimezone.c b/glib/gtimezone.c
index a37dbe2..145abc0 100644
--- a/glib/gtimezone.c
+++ b/glib/gtimezone.c
@@ -671,8 +671,9 @@ init_zone_from_iana_info (GTimeZone *gtz,
   guint extra_time_count = 0, extra_type_count = 0;
   gint64 last_explicit_transition_time;
 
-  g_return_if_fail (size >= sizeof (struct tzhead) &&
-                    memcmp (header, "TZif", 4) == 0);
+  g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier(size >= sizeof(struct tzhead) && 
+                                        memcmp(header, "TZif", 4) == 0,
+                                        identifier);
 
   /* FIXME: Handle invalid TZif files better (Issue#1088).  */
 
@@ -703,14 +704,14 @@ init_zone_from_iana_info (GTimeZone *gtz,
                              + guint32_from_be(header->tzh_charcnt));
       const gchar *footerlast;
       size_t footerlen;
-      g_return_if_fail (footer <= data + size - 2 && footer[0] == '\n');
+      g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier(footer <= data + size - 2 && footer[0] == '\n', identifier);
       footerlast = memchr (footer + 1, '\n', data + size - (footer + 1));
-      g_return_if_fail (footerlast);
+      g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier(footerlast != NULL, identifier);
       footerlen = footerlast + 1 - footer;
       if (footerlen != 2)
         {
           footertz = parse_footertz (footer, footerlen);
-          g_return_if_fail (footertz);
+          g_return_if_fail_with_free_identifier(footertz != NULL, identifier);
           extra_type_count = footertz->t_info->len;
           extra_time_count = footertz->transitions->len;
         }
-- 
2.12.3
```

@pwithnall Thanks for the review. Is the new wording in `supported-platforms.md` close to what you have in mind?

I moved the version check to be the first thing under darwin. I think it's a bit clearer there than inside the Carbon check.

target_title: Invalid UTF-8 reported from g_utf8_collate_key

note.body:
Ah, OK, makes sense.

Thanks, and sorry for the noise!

target_title: Invalid UTF-8 reported from g_utf8_collate_key

note.body:
> Is it really utf8, or just some random null-terminated bytes without a real encoding?

`type filename` means "OS native encoding": it never meant "UTF-8", otherwise it would not have been annotated that way.

The return value of `g_utf8_collate_key()` is a nul-terminated binary blob, not a string, and it most certainly is not a UTF-8 encoded string.

See: 0630b8145d3554ad0ac3a51250612da6c061a12f

target_title: Invalid UTF-8 reported from g_utf8_collate_key
Invalid UTF-8 reported from g_utf8_collate_key
Use getsockopt() styled API for GCredentials on FreeBSD

note.body:
I guess I figured now the source of confusion. Linux has both `G_CREDENTIALS_UNIX_CREDENTIALS_MESSAGE_SUPPORTED` and `G_CREDENTIALS_SOCKET_GET_CREDENTIALS_SUPPORTED` because both APIs return the same type `struct ucred`. But in FreeBSD and NetBSD (and probably other OSes) the `cmsg` API returns `struct cmsghdr` while the `getsockopt` one returns `[x]ucred`.

This makes it impossible to have both `G_CREDENTIALS_UNIX_CREDENTIALS_MESSAGE_SUPPORTED` and `G_CREDENTIALS_SOCKET_GET_CREDENTIALS_SUPPORTED` defined. We have to choose between these APIs and for reasons I outlined above I believe that `xucred` is preferable over control messages.

For instance, we're doing the same in the D-Bus code: https://github.com/FreeBSD/freebsd-ports/commit/04bd4bf4931ba794718f67ff5e693a679740bdad

target_title: glib/gbytes: Be more careful when saving a GBytes of NULL

note.body: Yeah sure.

target_title: g_signal_connect on "notify::non-existant-property" doesn't warn for invalid property

note.body:
The detail string is not part of the signal name: it's an additional element. That's why it's the "detail".

The documentation for `g_signal_connect()` and friends *could* be clearer:

- `detailed_signal` says: "A string of the form “signal-name::detail”", but the description should ensure that "signal-name" and "detail" are kept distinct
- "If the given signal doesn't exist" should be changed into "If the given signal name does not exist"
- there should be a link to the signals documentation

Feel free to open a merge request to that effect; there's no need to re-open this issue.

target_title: g_signal_connect on "notify::non-existant-property" doesn't warn for invalid property

note.body: `If the given signal doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted.` from docs gives the "impression" that all signal name validations are taken care of, when in fact `signal detail` validation is not. Adding a line on this to the docs would be helpful.

target_title: g_signal_connect on "notify::non-existant-property" doesn't warn for invalid property

note.body:
Signals have no idea about properties (or GObject in general), and there's no validation performed on the detail's quark; from the [GObject reference](https://docs.gtk.org/gobject/signals.html):

> While the detail argument is typically used to pass an object property name (as with GObject::notify), no specific format is mandated for the detail string, other than that it must be non-empty.

If this file is empty then your system is not installed correctly. GLib cannot and should not handle that: it relies on zoneinfo files, which are system data, being installed correctly.

Backport Unicode 16 support to 2.82

note.body:
We can’t backport any new codepoints without importing the whole Unicode 16 UCD, since all of GLib’s Unicode data is generated by script from the UCD. I don’t fancy trying to manually edit the data tables to support new characters, and can pretty much guarantee it will go wrong.

New codepoints being unsupported by a system until it has a new enough version of all the relevant bits of Unicode software is a fairly well-established phenomenon.

target_title: Backport Unicode 16 support to 2.82

note.body:
Technically, the changes in Unicode 16 (the new scripts, thousands of characters, etc.) don't matter to me. What I specifically want backported is support for the [8 new emoji](https://blog.emojipedia.org/whats-new-in-unicode-16-0/) from Unicode 16.

Test Case
---------
0. Install a suitable color emoji font. I recommend Noto Color Emoji 2.047
1. Build gnome-characters with https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-characters/-/merge_requests/133
2. Open gnome-characters
3. Search for fingerprint. The fingerprint emoji should show in search results.
4. In the sidebar, click People & Body. At the bottom of the emojis in the main area is fingerprint. It should show the graphical emoji. Instead, there is a box with the word Fingerprint.
5. Both 3 and 4 work with the big Unicode 16 merge request but do not work with glib 2.82.2

![image](/uploads/9f23443f8433b1752acaac25962b2e8c/image.png)

target_title: Bump minimum supported version of macOS

note.body:
OK, let’s try and wrap this up. We now have the following possible minimum versions:
 * 10.13, as supported by GStreamer
 * 10.15, as required by GTK
 * 11, as supported by the CI

We can’t bump our requirement higher than what GStreamer wants to support as a minimum, as GStreamer is a big user of GLib. But we can’t test on CI on versions older than 11 due to the architecture change.

So my suggestion would be:
 * Change `supported-platforms.md` to say we support 11, but have support for 10.13 on a best-effort basis
 * Change `meson.build` to require ≥10.13 (as per [this GTK MR](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/-/merge_requests/7881/diffs#0cc1139e3347f573ae1feee5b73dbc8a8a21fcfa))
 * Drop old conditional code for versions <10.13 (as listed in issue body)

Does that make sense to people? I hope I’ve summarised the discussion OK, I did get lost a bit in the cross-compilation options.

If so, would someone like to implement those changes? I can review an MR, but I’m not a macOS developer so can’t do a good job of writing one. :)

target_title: meson: Add variables to -uninstalled.pc files
meson: Add variables to -uninstalled.pc files
meson: Add variables to -uninstalled.pc files

note.body:
> I guess it depends on what the use case of `-uninstalled.pc` files is. I’m not totally clear on that.

The [Meson docs say](https://mesonbuild.com/Pkgconfig-module.html):
> Since 0.54.0 uninstalled pkg-config files are generated as well. They are located in `<build dir>/meson-uninstalled/`. It is sometimes useful to build projects against libraries built by Meson without having to install them into a prefix. In order to do so, just set `PKG_CONFIG_PATH=<builddir>/meson-uninstalled` before building your application. That will cause pkg-config to prefer those `-uninstalled.pc` files and find libraries and headers from the Meson builddir.

So yes, we probably do only want to expose read-only locations in `*-uninstalled.pc`.

tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body:
Ugh, it's more complicated than that. _Opening_ `/dev/fd/` should work & give you a copy of your existing fd. `readlink ()` on it won't work however.

There is an internal function in glibc to try & turn a directory handle into a path (which is how `getcwd ()` works for example), but AFAICS it's private, and there's no way that I know of to reconstruct a path for a non-directory file. It should be doable to add such an API, but there isn't one for now.

Generally it's a good idea to avoid paths and just use the fd / Mach port you already have (e.g. with `*at ()` style APIs), for all of the same reasons pidfds are a good idea.

g_date_time_new_from_unix_local issues system calls

note.body:
The `GTimeZone` set up cost is known; ideally, we could have a cache, but ensuring that it gets evicted when the tz data changes is problematic at best.

Adding a `g_date_time_new_from_unix()` with a `GTimeZone` parameter that lets you create a `GTimeZone` once for all calls would be possible; we can rename the current `g_date_time_new_from_unix()` to `g_date_time_new_from_unix_internal()` if we expose a call that takes a `gint64` as an alias to `time_t`.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: That's right, some parts of `/proc/%d/status` can also be obtained with sysctl-based API.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: Getting process information seems to be the job of libgtop, but libgtop can be cumbersome to use. It requires a setgid server program on FreeBSD, and it requires the caller to call `glibtop_init` (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libgtop/-/issues/44). It can leave zombie processes if it is used in a GNOME Shell extension and the user types `r` to restart GNOME Shell in an X11 environment.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: As far as I know, FreeBSD doesn't have /proc mounted by default. It is possible to have a fully working FreeBSD system with just two filesystem mounted: / (ufs) and /dev (devfs). Therefore, we should not depend on /proc on FreeBSD in GLib.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: As far as I know, the A suffix in Windows API means the legacy character encoding. The W suffix means Unicode in UTF-16. Thus, the W version is usually preferred to the A version.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
Out-of-bounds reading is definitely a C coding risk, as the behavior is undefined depending on both C compilers and memory allocator implementations. On some system, I even saw out-of-bounds reading on some dynamically allocated string resulted in some crash problem.

From the latest code, it looks g_str_is_ascii_valgrind is called when the code detects valgrind is just running. I'm afraid it can't mitigate the coding risk. Will g_str_is_ascii_valgrind directly replace g_str_is_ascii_native or there is a plan to find a risk-less fix in future?

target_title: Use getsockopt() styled API for GCredentials on FreeBSD

note.body:
To be honest, I was hoping you (glib people) explain this to me.

From what I gather, both `cmsg` and `getsockopt` may be used to obtain credentials of the other side. The difference is that when using `cmsg`, the client should actually send a special packet and the receiving side should accept it. When using `getsockopt` the "ours" side can get credentials without requiring the client to send us anything. It made me think that `getsockopt` is preferable over `cmsg`.

Anyways, the current glib code is not prepared for the case when both `G_CREDENTIALS_TYPE_SMTH` and `G_CREDENTIALS_UNIX_CREDENTIALS_MESSAGE_SUPPORTED` are defined.

Another data point is that `getpeereid` that is being talked in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/merge_requests/4402/diffs#3d0623082e172c321e5317063d44ad9f86fd8026_127_135 is actually implemented via `xucred` on FreeBSD.

So, my understanding of this stuff is also vague, but the change feels right to me.

Use getsockopt() styled API for GCredentials on FreeBSD

note.body:
Thanks for this. I think I need a bit more context to be able to review it effectively though:
 - I thought FreeBSD already had `struct cmsgcred` — is this now deprecated or something?
 - What advantages does `struct xucred` provide over `struct cmsgcred`? What disadvantages?
 - If `struct xucred` support is new, what minimum version of FreeBSD is it available on?
 - Basically, why are you proposing this change? :)

From some googling around, it looks like `struct cmsgcred` might still be the struct type for `SCM_CREDS` on a [socket control message](https://man.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=unix&sektion=4#CONTROL%09MESSAGES), whereas `struct xucred` is [retrieved](https://man.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=unix&sektion=4#SOCKET_OPTIONS) by calling `getsockopt(LOCAL_PEERCRED)` on a socket. I think this means that `SCM_CREDS` might no longer be supported after applying this MR? See `g_unix_credentials_message_get_msg_type()` in `gunixcredentialsmessage.c`.

target_title: nautilus NFS share permission of folders

note.body:
This issue caused by nfs4 ACL, Glusterfs doesn't support NFS4 ACL, so it should have been disabled by default. After adding Disable_ACL = TRUE; to the export blocks the issue disappeared.

It seems the NFS4 ACLs were populated, but the faulty folders didn't have "D - delete-child" permission

```nfs4_getfacl not_correct/
# file: not_correct/
A::OWNER@:rwaxtTcCy
A::GROUP@:rwaxtcy
A::EVERYONE@:rxtcy

nfs4_getfacl correct/
# file: correct/
A::OWNER@:rwaDxtTcCy
A::GROUP@:rwaDxtcy
A::EVERYONE@:rxtcy


trace -e getxattr gio info not_correct >/dev/null
getxattr("/nfs/not_correct/", "system.nfs4_acl", 0x7ffca2462090, 63) = -1 ERANGE (Numerical result out of range)
getxattr("/nfs/not_correct/", "system.nfs4_acl", NULL, 0) = 80
getxattr("/nfs/not_correct/", "system.nfs4_acl", "\0\0\0\3\0\0\0\0\0\0\0\0\0\26\1\247\0\0\0\6OWNER@\0\0\0\0\0", 80) = 80

After disabling NFS4 ACL:

fs4_getfacl correct/
Operation to request attribute not supported: correct/

trace -e getxattr gio info not_correct >/dev/null
getxattr("/nfs/correct/", "system.nfs4_acl", 0x7ffefb583d20, 63) = -1 EOPNOTSUPP (Operation not supported)```

tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: That’s a different load of data and a different use case. :) If you’d like to see a cross platform API for getting process information, please file a separate issue about that. But again note that GLib won’t [add new APIs unless there are](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md?ref_type=heads#user-content-features-and-enhancements) several consumers for them already, and a clear use case of what problem the API is solving.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: I suspect xdg-desktop-portal will want to continue using the low-level POSIX APIs, because they have fairly strict requirements about what they want to implement for fd sharing, and how to implement it. See the code in `verify_proc_self_fd()`, most of which would still need to exist even if xdg-desktop-portal used this API from GLib.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: Another relevant case that I bumped into when porting SSSD is `/proc/%d/status`. Although FreeBSD does have this pseudofile in /proc, it has a different format and can't be parsed by the code intended for Linux procfs.

target_title: tests: Factor out a function to convert FD to path

note.body: This is one of possible consumers of such API: https://github.com/flatpak/xdg-desktop-portal/blob/main/src/xdp-app-info.c#L405

I’m a bit wary of consuming the data without any feedback to the caller of `g_output_stream_write()`. How do they know when to stop splicing data in, even though the `GConverter` has finished? At the moment it seems this is only limited by the length of the input.

Or, put another way, if we were reimplementing the `gunzip` utility using GIO, how would we know when to print “decompression OK, trailing garbage ignored”?

Hi @kepstin, good point. I think !4133 removed the dependency on the packaging library. It looks like all that is left is standard library stuff like os, sys, re, optparse, datetime, xml, etc.

> There is no $PATH lookup when hardcoding an absolute filename, and people have noted that the absolute filename is incorrect in various contexts and vital in other contexts. Hi @eschwartz, so based on your feedback, it sounds like there are two main needs:

target_title: Windows build broken because of Python paths

note.body:
The absolute path was added specifically because in the configure step, a check was being performed to ensure that certain optional python libraries were available on the system. In order for that check to be valid, it was important that the scripts get run with *the same python* as the check was performed using.

This was done specifically with the intent of allowing someone to use a meson machine or cross file to specify the path to a specific python, which might not be the first python on the path, to use.

If the scripts in question have been updated so they no longer require any non-stdlib python modules (and work on a wide variety of python versions), then the absolute path code can probably just be removed completely along with the python module checks in the meson.build file.

Note that for distro packaging (the most common case of "build somewhere and run on someone else's computer" for Linux), absolute paths are generally preferred. Distros specifically want to make it so the installed script will always be run using the distro-packaged python, even if the user has a venv set up, since the venv python might not be compatible. But distro packagers are usually fine with rewriting shebang lines to distro standards (and might even have automatic tooling to handle that).

Windows build broken because of Python paths

note.body:
That makes no sense, since the purpose of `/user/bin/env` is to interject $PATH lookup and then execute the rest of the shebang line as the binary to execute.

If "the rest of the shebang line" is an absolute path then $PATH lookup has no effect as an absolute filepath is an absolute filepath regardless of the value of $PATH.

A shebang line is specified quite straightforward:
- `^#!(\s*)` is the leading bytes indicating that shebang processing shall be performed. The two shebang bytes can be followed by an optional run of ignored whitespace.
- then the interpreter, which is a filepath to execute directly. It's not a command to execute, it's a *filepath*. That's why it has to be an absolute path. It must not contain whitespace, period, end of story.
- whitespace terminates the interpreter filepath
- after that whitespace, the remainder of the line is passed as a *single* string argument to the interpreter

The `/usr/bin/env` program is a hack. A trick. A loophole in the rules. Its actual purpose is to accept multiple arguments containing an equals sign and treat each such argument as an environment variable to set in a subprocess, and once it runs out of environment variable specifiers, it executes the remaining arguments "as a command to run". Shebangs rely on the fact that "a command to run" includes $PATH lookup the same way "a command to run" inside bash performs $PATH lookup, in order to smuggle $PATH lookup into shebangs.

The sole point of `#!/usr/bin/env` as a shebang line is to do that $PATH lookup. It's not an intrinsic goal to use "env", it just... happens to do $PATH lookup.

There is no $PATH lookup when hardcoding an absolute filename, and people have noted that the absolute filename is incorrect in various contexts and vital in other contexts. You can't have it both ways, except by implementing a user option. But using `#!/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@` is not a valid answer for *anyone*.

target_title: Windows build broken because of Python paths

note.body:
I received a lot of feedback about using only `#!/usr/bin/env python3`, which is good since there has been many back and forth changes to the shebangs.

To allow for cross-compiling, a proposal is to:

1. Use `#!/usr/bin/env python3` if the Python executable is at `/usr/bin`.
2. If Python is not at `/usr/bin`, use `#!/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@`, where @PYTHON@ is the full path to Python.

This would also match the strategy recently changed in gobject-introspection. Are there any concerns with this approach? If not, I can update the MR.

Hi @pwithnall, good idea. This is a hard problem, for all the reasons outlined in https://peps.python.org/pep-0394/. 

I did it for gdbus-codegen.py as an example:

1. commit 0b9229beca5379b638e9d9a879bca30560042023

   Initial creation of file with the shebang hardcoded to `#!/usr/bin/python`

2. commit 33831bda2465c8f1e5d4a3fd2bf4e3618a812282

   Changed from hardcoded path to `@PYTHON@` to use detected python binary.
    @PYTHON@. Is used in Makefile.am to use detected python binary.

3. commit acb5b852c1175675d0edd2f05f76aefdaa29e1c7

   After a ton of discussion at https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=650763, moved from `@PYTHON@` to `/usr/bin/env python`.

4. commit 08cfcdc81add6f6f2247b1cc82d2c15ad27001f0

   Reverted the last change, saying that on Ubuntu it is called `python3`, so now we are back to `@PYTHON@` again.

5. commit 683809d5f751575775d12917581eb7b9a2acf0f5

   Changed from `@PYTHON@` to `/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@` to support Python 3 without an absolute path.

6. commit 013980d8398b1010c0e3414e5d1f06030fa557d2

   Reverted the last change and went to `@PYTHON@`, with the full path to Python. This introduced a bug since it now assumes that the path to Python has no spaces.

7. commit d2aac0908f9c1777c7512d5e35e73beae1f1dbc3

   My change from @PYTHON@ (full path) to `/usr/bin/env python3`


So a lot of back and forth and somewhat in circle changes. An advantage we have now is that python2 has been end of life for 4 years, so that eliminates some of the back and forth changes for `/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@` vs. `/usr/bin/env python`.

The current [Python docs for unix](https://docs.python.org/3/using/unix.html#miscellaneous) recommend using `/usr/bin/env python3` for shebangs. If users want to use a different Python than the one on their path, virtualenvs should be the solution.

note.body:
> They should not contain spaces in the command to run.

I am not sure if you have fully read my comment? I said:

> So, `#!/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@` where `PYTHON` is `python.full_path()` will work everywhere

target_title: Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body:
Hi @nirbheek, I should have been more specific with my response. They should not contain spaces in the command to run. So if you have Python at C:\Program Files\Python313, you get a shebang that looks like `#!C:\Program Files\Python313\python.exe`, which is not a valid shebang. It separates at the space, and then it tries to execute `C:\Program` which is not a valid executable.

I saw the use case linked above, but I don't understand it enough to try to reproduce it. I would think you would want to create a virtualenv containing the Python built for the target and then execute the script, not override a shebang.

target_title: Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body:
Shebangs can contain spaces just fine. The first space is considered as a delimiter, which separates the command to run and the (singular) argument to pass to it:

```
$ cd /tmp
$ ln -sfn `which python3` "py 3"
$ echo -e '#!/usr/bin/env /tmp/py 3\n\nprint("works!")' > foo
$ chmod +x foo
$ ./foo
works!
$ cat foo
#!/usr/bin/env /tmp/py 3

print("works!")
```

Here `env` is passed `/tmp/py 3` as the first (and only) argument, which is the command to run.

This is also how Meson parses shebangs on systems where they aren't natively supported, such as on Windows. So, `#!/usr/bin/env @PYTHON@` where `PYTHON` is `python.full_path()` will work everywhere, except that distros don't want a full path, they want `python3`, so when the full path is just `/usr/bin/<name>` then you don't use the full path. That's what the gobject-introspection patch does.

> It seems like users of a library should set up their environment so that the first python3 on their path is the Python they want to use.

Did you see the MR I have linked? The use-case is cross-compilation with gobject-introspection, which has to load python modules built for the target, which means it must run a python3 built for the target. On Linux it would use `qemu-kvm` and on macOS it uses `arch -x86_64`. You *have* to override the shebang.

target_title: Windows: fix Python path can contain spaces

note.body: Hi @nirbheek! Shebangs should not contain spaces, and that solution does not check for spaces in the Python path. It seems like users of a library should set up their environment so that the first python3 on their path is the Python they want to use. This could be done with a virtualenv, or through using the system Python if using a virtualenv is not desired.

target_title: refstring: Fix race between releasing and re-acquiring an interned GRefString

note.body:
If all you do with that global pointer then that's fine. But you can't have any code that "upgrades" that weak reference, that gives it out to other code after increasing the reference count.

That's exactly the bug here (and why `GWeakRef` exists and `g_object_add_weak_pointer()` says in the docs basically the same): threads trying to upgrade the weak reference can be racing with a thread dropping the last reference.

For the non-atomic refcounter that's not a problem because it can only be used from a single thread anyway.

The test can run until it’s done 10000 iterations, assuming that takes less than a couple of seconds.

target_title: Fix -Wshorten-64-to-32 warnings
Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
How hard does it hit performance if we take the `g_utf8_validate_valgrind` code path (with an explicit length limit) under all circumstances?

If a length is specified, it's the same code so there is certainly no impact.

If the length is left unspecified (negative), the impact would be that instead of iterating the string once (stopping at either `\0` or invalid UTF-8, whichever comes first), we would iterate it twice: once in `strlen()` looking for the `\0` to get the length, and then a second time looking for invalid UTF-8. That doesn't necessarily seem too bad?

That way, libc `strlen()` can have whatever UB optimizations it wants to have, but GLib will be scrupulously avoiding UB, and also wouldn't need ifuncs.

Similarly the commit message for cf982177 says

> I thought about just adding the `strlen()` call into `g_str_is_ascii()`
> unconditionally, as a simpler fix, but from a quick
> codesearch.debian.net, it appears `g_str_is_ascii()` is used quite
> widely, so this would have an unacceptable performance impact.

but was that prediction of an unacceptable performance impact based on benchmarking, or just a guess?

target_title: xdgmime: Aliases may cause infinite recursion

note.body:
Thanks for the detailed bug report. I think the [fix](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/commit/d9c50cac5d160798498e42d5b190ad89920a9a6a) you mentioned is the right one, and it needs to be backported to Ubuntu Jammy.

I have re-tested this on `main` by:
 1. Creating `~/.local/share/mime/packages/buggy.xml` with the contents below.
 2. Running `update-mime-database ~/.local/share/mime/`.
 3. Running `gio info --attributes standard::content-type /path/to/some/javascript/file` and verifying that it doesn’t infinitely loop, and it does produce a reasonable result (`text/javascript` in my case).
 4. Re-running `gio info` under gdb and breaking on [`xdgmimecache.c:1022`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/536dfca9bee9d8202d52df6a1b32afb74a73a75a/gio/xdgmime/xdgmimecache.c?page=2#L1022) to verify that the infinite loop detection code is working. (The breakpoint is hit.)

So I think this is fixed in `main`. You’ll need to report the issue to Ubuntu and ask for a backport of the fix from https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/merge_requests/3714 (and by extension, https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/xdg/xdgmime/-/merge_requests/29). If you can still reproduce the bug with GLib 2.82 or `main` then please reopen this issue. Thanks.

---

`buggy.xml`:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE mime-info [
<!ELEMENT mime-info (mime-type)+>
<!ATTLIST mime-info xmlns CDATA #FIXED "http://www.freedesktop.org/standards/shared-mime-info">
<!ELEMENT mime-type (comment+ , (acronym , expanded-acronym)? , (icon | generic-icon | glob | magic | treemagic | root-XML | alias | sub-class-of)*)>
<!ATTLIST mime-type type CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!-- a comment describing a document with the respective MIME type. Example: "WMV video" --><!ELEMENT comment (#PCDATA)>
<!ATTLIST comment xml:lang CDATA #IMPLIED>
<!-- a comment describing the respective unexpanded MIME type acronym. Example: "WMV" --><!ELEMENT acronym (#PCDATA)>
<!-- a comment describing the respective expanded MIME type acronym. Example: "Windows Media Video" --><!ELEMENT expanded-acronym (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT icon EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST icon name CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!-- a generic icon name as per the Icon Naming Specification, only required if computing
  it from the mime-type would not work, See "generic-icon" in the Shared Mime Specification --><!ELEMENT generic-icon EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST generic-icon name (application-x-executable | audio-x-generic | folder | font-x-generic | image-x-generic | package-x-generic | text-html | text-x-generic | text-x-generic-template | text-x-script | video-x-generic | x-office-address-book | x-office-calendar | x-office-document | x-office-presentation | x-office-spreadsheet) #REQUIRED>
<!ELEMENT glob EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST glob pattern CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ATTLIST glob weight CDATA "50">
<!ATTLIST glob case-sensitive CDATA #IMPLIED>
<!ELEMENT magic (match)+>
<!ATTLIST magic priority CDATA "50">
<!ELEMENT match (match)*>
<!ATTLIST match offset CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ATTLIST match type (string | big16 | big32 | little16 | little32 | host16 | host32 | byte) #REQUIRED>
<!ATTLIST match value CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ATTLIST match mask CDATA #IMPLIED>
<!ELEMENT treemagic (treematch)+>
<!ATTLIST treemagic priority CDATA "50">
<!ELEMENT treematch (treematch)*>
<!ATTLIST treematch path CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ATTLIST treematch type (file | directory | link) #IMPLIED>
<!ATTLIST treematch match-case (true | false) #IMPLIED>
<!ATTLIST treematch executable (true | false) #IMPLIED>
<!ATTLIST treematch non-empty (true | false) #IMPLIED>
<!ATTLIST treematch mimetype CDATA #IMPLIED>
<!ELEMENT root-XML EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST root-XML namespaceURI CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ATTLIST root-XML localName CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ELEMENT alias EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST alias type CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ELEMENT sub-class-of EMPTY>
<!ATTLIST sub-class-of type CDATA #REQUIRED>
]>
<!--
The freedesktop.org shared MIME database (this file) was created by merging
several existing MIME databases (all released under the GNU GPL).

It comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law. You may
redistribute copies of freedesktop.org.xml under the terms of the GNU General
Public License version 2 or later. For more information about these matters,
see the file named COPYING.

The latest version is available from:

	http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/shared-mime-info/

To extend this database, users and applications should create additional
XML files in the 'packages' directory and run the update-mime-database
command to generate the output files.
-->
<mime-info xmlns="http://www.freedesktop.org/standards/shared-mime-info">
  <mime-type type="application/ecmascript">
    <comment>ECMAScript program</comment>
    <alias type="text/ecmascript"/>
    <sub-class-of type="text/javascript"/>
    <generic-icon name="text-x-script"/>

Win32: Incomplete GIO Gir file

note.body:
Ah, that makes sense. `GNetworkMonitorBase` is an internal class which is used as the base of the implementation for the win32, macOS, portal and netlink network monitor implementations. It’s only exposed in the public API here because `GWin32NetworkMonitor` is exposed publicly — it’s not exposed by the other network monitor implementations as they’re all hidden.

Given that there’s no usable public API in `gwin32networkmonitor.h`, I propose the fix here would be to make `GWin32NetworkMonitor` private, just like the other network monitors are. This should be possible by removing `'gwin32networkmonitor.h'` from `win32_sources`. Would you be able to test that and put together a merge request please? I cannot easily test on Windows.

Another potential fix would be to make `GNetworkMonitorBase` public, but that’s quite a bit more complex, as it has various methods on it which would need to remain private.

target_title: Win32: Incomplete GIO Gir file

note.body:
* It references `GNetworkMonitorBase`.
* It is not referenced in one of the include files.

The gir file defines it as:

```xml
<record name="Win32NetworkMonitor" c:type="GWin32NetworkMonitor">
      <source-position filename="gio/gwin32networkmonitor.h" line="45"/>
      <field name="parent_instance" introspectable="0" writable="1">
        <type c:type="GNetworkMonitorBase"/>
      </field>
      <field name="priv" writable="1">
        <type name="Win32NetworkMonitorPrivate"
              c:type="GWin32NetworkMonitorPrivate*"/>
      </field>
</record>
```

So same applies to the "priv" field, which references `GWin32NetworkMonitorPrivate` and is not defined in any of the gir files, too.

Additionally there is a record in the gir regarding the corresponding class:

```xml
<record name="Win32NetworkMonitorClass" c:type="GWin32NetworkMonitorClass">
      <source-position filename="gio/gwin32networkmonitor.h" line="49"/>
      <field name="parent_class" introspectable="0" writable="1">
        <type c:type="GNetworkMonitorBaseClass"/>
      </field>
</record>
```

The `GNetworkMonitorBaseClass` is not defined, too.

2 of the 3 unknown fields are marekd as `introspectable=0` but I'm not sure if this should allow the gir file to be inconsistent.

target_title: Draft: Use python3 as the shebang on Windows

note.body:
> Can we definitely not do that? What about backslash-escaping the space?

Yes, we could implement that on the Meson side very easily: https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/blob/1.6.0/mesonbuild/programs.py#L173. However note that bash itself doesn't parse shebangs when it executes a script. For example:

```
myscript.txt
----------------
#!/usr/bin/echo hello\ world
```

```
$ chmod +x myscript.txt
$ ./myscript.txt
hello\ world ./myscript.txt
```

Same with quotes:

```
myscript.txt
----------------
#!/usr/bin/echo "hello world"
```

```
$ chmod +x myscript.txt
$ ./myscript.txt
"hello world" ./myscript.txt
```

So I don't think shell-quoting shebangs is portable. It will work in Meson, but not elsewhere (shells).

Additionally, inserting the path to the build-time Python is leaking build-time informations, which can mess checksums or reproducible builds.

I'm open to any solution, just wanted to point these things out :)

g_filename_from_uri rejects valid host names according to RFC 1123

note.body: What you need to know about URLs is that the WhatWG spec and IETF RFCs are just not going to agree on how URLs work. The WhatWG spec is what web browsers do, and it's what WebKit and libsoup and Epiphany all expect when they use GUri. But GUri doesn't implement that; it implements RFC 3986, which has many differences, which could likely cause all sorts of subtle bugs. But I don't know what, because I'm not an expert on the URL specs. This commit is not touching GUri, but for sanity purposes, GLib should probably stick to consistently following RFC 3986, which says: > A host identified by a registered name is a sequence of characters usually intended for lookup within a locally defined host or service name registry, though the URI's scheme-specific semantics may require that a specific registry (or fixed name table) be used instead. The most common name registry mechanism is the Domain Name System (DNS). A registered name intended for lookup in the DNS uses the syntax defined in [Section 3.5 of \[RFC1034\]](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc1034#section-3.5) and [Section 2.1 of \[RFC1123\]](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc1123#section-2.1). There's a bunch more verbosity, but TL;DR is it references back to RFC 1123 and suggests we should accept these.
