target_title: GDBusProxy::g-name-owner emits empty GVariant dictionary in ‘g-properties-changed' Signal

note.body:
I think `GDBusProxy` is behaving exactly as it’s meant to. The [documentation](https://docs.gtk.org/gio/class.DBusProxy.html) says “If the proxy is for a well-known name, the property cache is flushed when the name owner vanishes and reloaded when a name owner appears.”, and that’s what’s happening here.

`changed_properties` is empty, but `invalidated_properties` is full. Your code needs to pay attention to both of them, not just `changed_properties`.

> I propose a proper fix would involve iterating over the property names in the hash table and setting each to a NULL value

It’s not possible to set the value of an `a{sv}` element to `NULL`, there is no such thing as a `NULL` variant.

thread: Force-limit thread name length

note.body:
Hang on, this code path is used for multiple platforms. In particular, FreeBSD’s implementation of `pthread_setname_np()` isn’t [documented](https://man.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=pthread_setname_np&apropos=0&sektion=0&manpath=FreeBSD+14.1-RELEASE+and+Ports&arch=default&format=html) as having any length restrictions.

I think it would be more robust to impose this limit in `g_system_thread_set_name()`, and only for the platforms where we know a length limit is imposed (i.e. Linux).

That also means that the full thread name can still be accessed via `thread->name` and printed out in debug messages or gdb, even if it’s truncated in `ps` output.

Silent linked-list corruption in g_static_resource_init() on redundant calls

note.body:
I added https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/merge_requests/4372. I think it adds a useful validation to the function and it guards against insertion of items that are already in another list, but I am not convinced that it guards against the scenario that I am reporting since the existing item would be at the end of the list and thus next would still be NULL.

# Example:

If during the first call `static_resource` points to `A` and `lazy_register_resources == NULL` (list end), then we insert A and then `lazy_register_resources` points to `A`. `A->next` is still `NULL`.

If during the second call `static_resource` still points to `A` and `lazy_register_resources == A`,
then set `next == A` and then `static_resource->next = A` (now the list is circular).

So the check `static_resource->next == NULL` would not trigger in the case where A was the first and only item in the list.

Does this make sense or did I miss something?

target_title: refstring: Fix race between releasing and re-acquiring an interned GRefString

note.body:
Actually, `sizeof(GRefStringImpl)` already is 16 bytes on 64 bit platforms due to padding after `s` to provide correct alignment for the `gsize len`. (and 12 bytes on 32 bit platforms)

So we would allocate the same amount of memory anyway.

target_title: refstring: Fix race between releasing and re-acquiring an interned GRefString

note.body: This always places the first character of the string on an odd address (8 + 4 + 1 = 13 on 64 bit platforms, 4 + 4 + 1 = 9 on 32 bit platforms). Should we align this, and if so how much? Previously this was always `2*sizeof(gsize)` aligned, which would mean to put it at offset 16. The UTF-8 SIMD optimizations want `sizeof(gsize)` alignment AFAIU.

### Steps to reproduce

```bash
mkdir tmp-compile
cd tmp-compile

git clone --depth=1 https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib.git
git clone --depth=1 https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gobject-introspection.git

export CC=gcc

cd glib
LDFLAGS="-fsanitize=address" CFLAGS="-ggdb3 -O1 -fsanitize=address -fno-omit-frame-pointer -fno-common" meson setup builddir --prefix=/usr/temp --buildtype=plain --wrap-mode=nofallback -Dsysprof=disabled -Dtests=false -Db_lundef=false
LDFLAGS="-fsanitize=address" meson compile -C builddir
sudo meson install -C builddir

export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/temp/lib
export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/temp/lib/pkgconfig

cd ../gobject-introspection
git submodule update --init --recursive
meson setup builddir --prefix=/usr/temp --buildtype=plain -Dglib_src_dir="$(pwd)/../glib"
ASAN_OPTIONS="verify_asan_link_order=0" meson compile -C builddir

```

target_title: gstring: utilize allocated_len in g_string_replace

note.body: Yes, but how often does that happen in real world use cases, and what’s the performance impact of the extra allocation? My guess would be “not often” and “unmeasurably low”.

target_title: gstring: utilize allocated_len in g_string_replace

note.body: Interesting observation: this will always avoid allocation for small strings (where r_len > f_len && new_len + 1 + old_len <= 64) since g_string_sized_new allocates at least 64 bytes at minimum (glibc malloc allocates 24 or 12).

target_title: gstring: utilize allocated_len in g_string_replace

note.body: And incrementing the base of `string->str` without changing `string->len` or `string->allocated_len` is asking for a buffer overflow.

target_title: gstring: utilize allocated_len in g_string_replace

note.body: Sharing the buffer between two `GString`s is going to be incredibly hard for people to reason about when editing this code in future.

target_title: gstring: utilize allocated_len in g_string_replace

note.body:
What’s your use case? This is already quite complex code, and this complicates the code even further (adding another place where we lose encapsulation of initialisation/allocation of a `GString`), to save one allocation in situations where a `GString` has previously been over-allocated (or appended to and then shortened) before calling `g_string_replace()` on it.

That sequence of events seems pretty unlikely to happen to me, and hence not worth the additional code complexity.

refstring: Fix race between releasing and re-acquiring an interned GRefString

note.body:
> Alternatives to some private `gatomicrefcount` API would be to not use the refcounting helpers at all and implement it manually, or to deprecate `g_ref_string_new_intern()` and just consider it broken.

I think this’ll have to be the approach, but that’s only a rough estimate; I haven’t planned out a concrete approach for the fix in my head. The fix needs to allow for tight synchronisation between the atomic refcount and the `interned_ref_strings` lock. Maybe prototype something and submit a draft for review if you want early feedback on the approach.

If private helpers were added to `gatomicrefcount`, my guess is they’d have to change the internal invariants about the atomic ref count (i.e. that it can never reach zero) and that will either make maintenance of the public API harder, or introduce bugs. i.e Even if the addition to the API was private, it would still have an effect on the public API.

target_title: GSource needs an after_poll() vfunc for Wayland FDs

note.body:
It can't be an _actual_ vfunc since there's no space left in the GSourceFuncs struct, but we could achieve the same goal by doing something comparable to `g_source_set_dispose_function()`, e.g. `g_source_set_after_poll_function()`.

I'd also say the documentation of `GSourceFuncs.check` needs to be enhanced to clarify that source priorities are considered before calling check, because I had incorrectly assumed that check _does_ always called after poll.

target_title: Add a G_DECLARE macro for "protected" types

 * MyAppWindow *my_app_window_new (void);
 *
 * …
```

target_title: Add a G_DECLARE macro for "protected" types

note.body:
```suggestion:-5+0
 * @ModuleObjName: the name of the new type, in camel case (like `GtkWidget`)
 * @module_obj_name: the name of the new type in lowercase, with words
 *   separated by `_` (like `gtk_widget`)
 * @MODULE: the name of the module, in all caps (like `GTK`)
 * @OBJ_NAME: the bare name of the type, in all caps (like `WIDGET`)
 * @ParentName: the name of the parent type, in camel case (like `GtkWidget`)
```

(See https://developer.gnome.org/documentation/guidelines/devel-docs.html#writing-api-references — I haven’t been particularly thorough though, there might still be advice which applies)

    #5 0x61519ebda52c in gvdb_hash_table_insert_string subprojects/gvdb/gvdb/gvdb-builder.c:124:30
    #6 0x61519ebd9548 in output_schema gio/glib-compile-schemas.c:1728:5
    #7 0x78b886b9e9b1 in g_hash_table_foreach glib/ghash.c:2128:9
    #8 0x61519ebd2e62 in write_to_file gio/glib-compile-schemas.c:1758:3
    #9 0x61519ebd2e62 in main gio/glib-compile-schemas.c:2318:20
    #10 0x78b886745e07 in __libc_start_call_main /usr/src/debug/glibc/glibc/csu/../sysdeps/nptl/libc_start_call_main.h:58:16
    #11 0x78b886745ecb in __libc_start_main /usr/src/debug/glibc/glibc/csu/../csu/libc-start.c:360:3
    #12 0x61519ea9cbc4 in _start (/usr/temp/bin/glib-compile-schemas+0x77bc4)
```

I also saw these compiler warnings:
```
../glib/gutf8.c:1894:1: warning: unused function 'resolve_g_utf8_validate' [-Wunused-function]
 1894 | resolve_g_utf8_validate (void)
      | ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
../glib/gutf8.c:1995:1: warning: unused function 'resolve_g_str_is_ascii' [-Wunused-function]
 1995 | resolve_g_str_is_ascii (void)
      | ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
2 warnings generated.

```

The GVFS build succeeds if I add a `no_sanitize_address` attribute to `load_word`, for what it's worth:
```diff
diff --git a/glib/gutf8.c b/glib/gutf8.c
index bca3358..68e520d 100644
--- a/glib/gutf8.c
+++ b/glib/gutf8.c
@@ -1607,6 +1607,9 @@ load_u8 (gconstpointer memory,
 # define _attribute_aligned(n)
 #endif
 
+#if g_macro__has_attribute(no_sanitize_address)
+  __attribute__((no_sanitize_address))
+#endif
 static inline gsize
 load_word (gconstpointer memory,
            gsize         offset)
```


### Steps to reproduce
```bash
mkdir tmp-compile
cd tmp-compile

git clone --depth=1 https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib.git
git clone --depth=1 https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs.git

export CC=clang
export LDFLAGS="-fuse-ld=lld -fsanitize=address"
export CFLAGS="-ggdb3 -O1 -fsanitize=address -fno-omit-frame-pointer -fno-common"

cd glib
meson setup builddir --prefix=/usr/temp --buildtype=plain --wrap-mode=nofallback -Dsysprof=disabled -Dtests=false -Db_lundef=false
meson compile -C builddir
sudo meson install -C builddir

export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/temp/lib
export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/temp/lib/pkgconfig

cd ../gvfs
meson setup builddir --prefix=/usr/temp --buildtype=plain --wrap-mode=nofallback -Dgoa=false -Dgoogle=false -Dgphoto2=false -Dmtp=false -Dnfs=false -Donedrive=false -Dsmb=false -Db_lundef=false
meson compile -C builddir
sudo LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/temp/lib meson install -C builddir
```

The motivation is to avoid the parsing overhead of the hex-encoded string literal. Some compilers also have length limitations for string literals, afaik.

GTK is currently using a hack involving `ld -b binary` (that is what the --external-data option is for), but it is not very portable and has caused some trouble.

target_title: tests: Fix calls to deprecated API in unix-mounts tests

note.body:
> And having to rewrite it when the deprecated API is removed. As long as the old functions do nothing more than call the new ones it's hard to argue that they need testing.

The deprecated APIs will be removed no earlier than GLib 3, which is not on any roadmaps for the foreseeable future, so this is not going to cause a problem.

It’s easy to argue that the functions need testing, because every function which is not tested lowers the code coverage score. The lower the score, the harder it is to find the functions which *do* actually need testing (because they’re more complex) amongst the noise of things which don’t-need-testing-but-we-can’t-tell-the-tools-that.

target_title: tests: Fix calls to deprecated API in unix-mounts tests

note.body:
> Actually, a better approach for the unit tests would be to consistently call the _old_ APIs, as they all immediately call the new APIs. Then we get coverage of both old and new for free, at the cost of putting `G_GNUC_BEGIN_IGNORE_DEPRECATIONS` at the top of the test file.

And having to rewrite it when the deprecated API is removed. As long as the old functions do nothing more than call the new ones it's hard to argue that they need testing.

glib 2.82.2 Build failure on openEuler due to gtester: Failed to close file descriptor for child process

note.body:
Thanks for the log. The relevant line is:
```
2024-10-22 16:33:30 [pid 11528] close_range(3, 4294967295, CLOSE_RANGE_CLOEXEC) = -1 EPERM (Operation not permitted)
```

`close_range()` is not documented to return `EPERM`, but that does point us to the right issue: I think you’re either running with an old version of Docker, which doesn’t return `ENOSYS` correctly for unrecognised syscalls (like, presumably, `close_range()`). Or your build machine has some other seccomp policy which is returning the wrong error code for `close_range()`.

In both cases, you either need to upgrade your build machines, or carry a local patch to GLib which causes it to fall back to `safe_fdwalk()` if `close_range()` fails with `EPERM` in `glib-unix.c` (there are two functions in that file which would need to be changed).

See commit ce04a124040be091407e070280d86ca810bacb8c and issue #2580 for details. Or https://gitlab.gnome.org/Infrastructure/GitLab/-/issues/545 or https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/43595 for some more examples of how this Docker issue has been fixed/worked around in other CI setups.

This is useful for people who have to target slightly older versions of GLib with their applications, to know which APIs will be available to them.

That’s because this invalid read is happening via `g_str_is_ascii()` rather than `g_utf8_validate()`. Those two are the only two public APIs which call into the vectored validation code, but we only mitigated `g_utf8_validate()` so far.

Draft: resources: Support C23 #embed

note.body:
Interesting idea.

What advantages does it provide over the existing options to `glib-compile-resources`? Presumably it overcomes array size limits and means the generated source file is a lot smaller (so build directories get a bit smaller)? I’ve not come across `#embed` before so don’t really know.

It would be good to briefly mention the advantages/disadvantages of using this option in the `.rst` file, to help users in making their decisions about which option to use.

A unit test is also needed — see the code around `resources_extra_sources` in `gio/tests/meson.build`.

target_title: Draft: resources: Support C23 #embed

note.body: Might want to add some ‘see also’ references to this from the other embedding options, like `--external-data`. And mention that it’s mutually exclusive with `--external-data` and with the default approach which is taken when neither option is specified. (Maybe the default approach should now get its own `--embed-literal` option, for clarity?)

target_title: Draft: resources: Support C23 #embed

note.body:
```suggestion:-0+0
    { "embed-data", 0, 0, G_OPTION_ARG_FILENAME, &embed_data, N_("Don’t embed resource data in the C file; use C23 #embed instead"), N_("FILENAME") },
```

Although actually would it make more sense to rephrase this as something like “Use C23 #embed to embed resource data in the C file”? From [what I’ve briefly read](https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/preprocessor/embed) on `#embed`, it effectively preprocesses the file into an array in the preprocessor output. So it *is* embedded in the C file, I think?

target_title: Update to Unicode 16.0.0 and fix Unicode composition for its new codepoints

note.body:
The Unicode consortium did actually highlight the problems which Tulu-Tigalari’s decompositions might cause implementations: https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr15/tr15-56.html#Contexts_Care

I haven’t explicitly added extra tests for these decompositions/normalisation contexts, because they’re well covered in the `NormalizationTest.txt` file which comes with the Unicode Character Database, and which we include and run as our `unicode-normalize.c` test.

note.body:
> I needed a FINAL class with a signal that has a RUN implementation

You can specify a class closure for the signal as a callback using [`g_signal_new_class_handler()`](https://docs.gtk.org/gobject/func.signal_new_class_handler.html), you don't need an offset to a function pointer in the class structure.

target_title: Add a G_DECLARE macro for "protected" types

note.body: FWIW, I had another use-case for this macro recently: I needed a FINAL class with a signal that has a RUN implementation. In that case I need to be able to declare the Class structure in my .c file. It can be done using G_DECLARE_DERIVABLE_TYPE but the naming is a bit wrong for something that is not meant to be derivable, and it forces using a private struct when I could be just defining my instance struct in the .c file as well.

target_title: g_array_free and free_seg

note.body:
Okay, I'm going to prepare one.

While looking deeper I noticed that there is related issue with `g_ptr_array_free` too (please note `free_seg` everywhere vs. `free_segment` in the function definition):
```
/**
 * g_ptr_array_free:
 * @array: a #GPtrArray
 * @free_seg: if %TRUE the actual pointer array is freed as well
 *
 * Frees the memory allocated for the #GPtrArray. If @free_seg is %TRUE
 * it frees the memory block holding the elements as well. Pass %FALSE
 * if you want to free the #GPtrArray wrapper but preserve the
 * underlying array for use elsewhere. If the reference count of @array
 * is greater than one, the #GPtrArray wrapper is preserved but the
 * size of @array will be set to zero.
 *
 * If array contents point to dynamically-allocated memory, they should
 * be freed separately if @free_seg is %TRUE and no #GDestroyNotify
 * function has been set for @array.
 *            
 * Note that if the array is %NULL terminated and @free_seg is %FALSE
 * then this will always return an allocated %NULL terminated buffer.
 * If pdata is previously %NULL, a new buffer will be allocated.
 *
 * This function is not thread-safe. If using a #GPtrArray from multiple
 * threads, use only the atomic g_ptr_array_ref() and g_ptr_array_unref()
 * functions.
 *
 * Returns: (transfer full) (nullable): the pointer array if @free_seg is
 *     %FALSE, otherwise %NULL. The pointer array should be freed using g_free().
 */ 
gpointer*
g_ptr_array_free (GPtrArray *array,
                  gboolean   free_segment)
{
```
I'm going to change all `free_seg` to `free_segment` for consistency.

target_title: glib 2.82.2 Build failure on openEuler due to gtester: Failed to close file descriptor for child process

note.body:
The “Failed to close file descriptor for child process” message can only result from a `CHILD_CLOSE_FAILED` error being propagated from a spawn child to its parent. That can only happen if `g_closefrom()` or `g_fdwalk_set_cloexec()` fail.

Can you please re-run the failing `gtester` command under `strace --follow-forks` to see what syscall is failing.

target_title: "gio mount --list --detail" shows can_mount=0 while the drive actually is mountable

note.body:
The [basic GLib implementation of `can_mount`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/main/gio/gunixvolume.c?ref_type=heads#L226) always returns `TRUE`, so this looks like it’s a bug in whatever VFS implementation of `GVolume` you’re using (probably GVFS, but maybe something provided by xfce).

What does the ‘type’ field in the `gio mount --list --detail` output say? It’s probably something like `Type: GProxyVolume (GProxyVolumeMonitorUDisks2)`.

note.body: Indeed, that’s a typo in the docs. Merge request welcome to fix it :grin:

target_title: Determine policy on 32-bit support

note.body:
What does armhf mean in this context? Debian's armhf architecture is ARM EABI hardfloat with ARMv7 as its baseline (minimum functionality level), but from your other architecture being named armv7 and less-deprecated, I assume it probably isn't the same as that.

(From the references to Raspberry Pi v1, perhaps your armhf is ARM EABI hardfloat with ARMv6 as its baseline, which is the same thing that 32-bit Raspberry Pi OS targets?)

Now that we have CI for Debian i386 (!4358), that should catch any regressions that are generic to all ILP32 architectures and not specific to ARM or Alpine.

target_title: Determine policy on 32-bit support

note.body: Thanks for letting us know. I think the policy we’ve come up with should be compatible with your needs. Would you mind taking a look at !4360 and commenting on it if you think it’s not a good idea, or if something is missing? Thanks.

Add a CI job for Debian stable i386 (32-bit)

note.body: :ship:

target_title: Determine policy on 32-bit support

note.body:
Sorry for not being a part of this discussion earlier, but we're at Alpine are also still supporting 32-bit Platforms (x86, armv7, armhf). [armhf is supported on a best-effort basis and isn't release-crtical](https://lists.alpinelinux.org/~alpine/devel/<20200528104748.4d37ede5@ncopa-desktop.copa.dup.pw>), but armv7 and x86 are most likely supported at least for a few years, if not more.

This is particulary important for postmarketOS, the downstream distro of Alpine targeted towards mobile devices. As many devices only support 32-bit kernels, it is not possible to migrate all devices to 64-bit kernels :(. And a phone without GLib is almost useless. See also [this pmOS issue](https://gitlab.postmarketos.org/postmarketOS/pmaports/-/issues/599) trying to migrate armhf devices to armv7 kernels.

target_title: Add a CI job for Debian stable i386 (32-bit)

note.body: This is looking promising so far - some other build passes haven't run yet, but `debian-stable-i386` succeeded.

target_title: Add a CI job for Debian stable i386 (32-bit)

note.body:
> Another possible short-term solution might be to get `ninja-build` from `pip` instead of from Debian, if there's a newer version available from there

The version available via `pip` is the same as the version in Debian 12 (plus an unrelated feature addition), so, equally slightly too old to handle large inode numbers on 32-bit systems.

target_title: Add a CI job for Debian stable i386 (32-bit)

note.body: `registry.gitlab.gnome.org/gnome/glib/debian-stable-i386:v2` builds and installs a local backport of the `ninja-build` that I've suggested should be in the next Debian 12 point release. Let's see whether that works...

note.body:
This is turning out to be a bigger job than I thought, as our composition code (`g_unichar_compose()` but also, by extension, `g_utf8_normalize()`) can’t handle compositions of a repeating codepoint, and some of those have been introduced (for the first time, I assume) in Unicode 16.0.

For example, U+113C5 (Tulu-Tigalari Vowel Sign Ai) decomposes to U+113C2 U+113C2 (Tulu-Tigalari Vowel Sign Ee, twice). The `compose_data` table is designed to assume that a given codepoint (such as U+113C2) will only be looked up in it as a first character in a decomposition, *or* as a second character, but not both. Tulu-Tigalari is new in Unicode 16.0.

(There’s a nice viewer for the Unicode character data [here](https://www.unicode.org/charts/nameslist/) which gives the decomposition using the `≡` annotation beneath each codepoint entry.)

And in fact this has been highlighted in the changes to UAX15: https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr15/tr15-56.html#Contexts_Care

So I need to do some work to rearrange that.

note.body:
> If it isn’t accepted into 12.7, then we could build the i386 image on Debian 13 and keep the x86_64 image on Debian 12. (I’d prefer to keep testing on Debian 12 in _some_ form while it’s still supported.)

I think Debian 12 is definitely something we should be testing on, as our representative of a not-too-old but not-the-newest LTS platform (unless we want to use Ubuntu or RHEL or some other LTS platform instead, but we already have test coverage on Debian and it's a platform I know well, so I think it makes sense to stick with Debian).

Until/unless 32-bit ninja-build gets fixed in Debian 12, we could consider doing our 32-bit testing on Debian `testing` (an alpha/beta/preview of the *next* Debian stable release, which currently means Debian 13). Normally I would say that `testing` doesn't have a huge amount of value because it's too close to what's in Fedora to really improve coverage, but in this case, the fact that it's 32-bit *does* improve coverage.

Another possible short-term solution might be to get `ninja-build` from `pip` instead of from Debian, if there's a newer version available from there. We're using Meson from `pip` anyway.

gmain: Include poll.h as early as possible, fixing build on AIX

note.body:
When writing commit messages, please imagine that your commit message is being read by an overworked maintainer (possibly you!), many years into the future, trying to understand the history of the code so that you can solve a serious bug. The commit message should say what is changing and why, without needing to refer to an external issue tracker for basic information.

So, instead of `Fix for GNOME/glib#3500`, perhaps something like this would be better:

```
gmain: Include poll.h as early as possible

On AIX, the system poll.h redefines the names of struct members,
for example `#define events reqevents`. This means that accesses
to GPollFD will fail to compile if poll.h was included after
glib/gpoll.h.

We can't simply add `#include <poll.h>` in glib/gpoll.h, because
that wouldn't work on platforms where poll.h doesn't exist, and
GLib supports some platforms in that category.

Resolves: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/3500
```

This captures all of the key facts:

* the bug fix was to move the `#include` of `poll.h` earlier
* it was intended to help AIX
* the key requirement is that `#include <poll.h>` comes before `#include <glib/gpoll.h>`
* this is necessary because AIX's system headers have `#define events reqevents` and similar things that break reasonable expectations about namespacing
* why we couldn't use the simpler solution

in a reasonably concise bit of text, and then directs the reader to the issue tracker if they need more details.

target_title: gmain: Include poll.h as early as possible, fixing build on AIX

note.body:
Ideally, a reader should be able to understand what we are doing without needing to refer to external resources like the issue tracker. That's not always feasible, but in this case surely we can do better.

Perhaps something like this:

```suggestion:-2+0
/* We need to include this as early as possible, because on some
 * platforms like AIX, <poll.h> redefines the names we use for
 * GPollFD struct members.
 * See https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/3500 */
```

note.body: @smcv Ms. Palmer's solution is correct. You can read tzfile(5) if you want the gory details, but the tl;dr is that there's an array of `struct ttinfo`. In an abstract TZ like PST8PDT there are two of them, standard and daylight. In an historical one like Los Angeles there are three, the first being Local Mean Time, or LMT, that is determined by setting Noon as the point that the sun is at the highest altitude angle for the day. This test relied on `ttinfo[0]` being standard time and `ttinfo[1]` being daylight time. She changes that to calling `g_timezone_find_interval()` to get the correct standard and daylight indexes for `ttinfo`.

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
Thanks for the input. These are valid concerns.

(I am definitely not an expert on UB or compiler optimisations.)

I’m tempted to think that this code is fine. The code is in a loop, so the instructions executed on each iteration are the same. I can’t see how it could break due to UB on the final iteration but not any of the preceding iterations, given that the array bounds (for the purposes of calculating UB) are a compile-time construct rather than a runtime one. The generated code has to work on inputs which are a multiple of the word size in length and which aren’t. I guess it’s possible for the compiler to infer that the input *must* be a multiple of the word size in length, due to how it’s accessed, so it might optimise away the final byte-based iterations of the loop?

Note that while this code has been in c-utf8 since 2018, and that’s been in use in systemd on a lot of systems, it’s always been passing a length into the validation function. So that’s not quite the same call pattern as GLib can use.

Looking at glibc, they do [word-based string reads](https://github.com/bminor/glibc/blob/2c1903cbbac0022153a67776f474c221250ad6ed/string/strchrnul.c#L49), but use a [type which is defined as `__attribute__((__may_alias__))`](https://github.com/bminor/glibc/blob/2c1903cbbac0022153a67776f474c221250ad6ed/sysdeps/x86_64/x32/string-optype.h). I’m not sure if `__may_alias__` would help us, since both `utf8_verify()` and `utf8_verify_ascii()` don’t really use any internal variables which could cause problems by aliasing. The code already avoids aliasing warnings through its use of `load_word()`.

Given that both validation functions are read-only (they never write to the string being validated), I’m not sure how reordering of memory operations could cause any problems either.

So I’d be inclined to leave this code as-is. If a compiler decides to optimise it in a weird way in future, there are enough regression tests for its functionality in the GLib test suite that the change should be caught before it gets into the wild.

target_title: glib/gutf8: use ifunc to check for valgrind

note.body:
FWIW I didn't format it this way on purpose, because it's the most convoluted C syntax in existence. Putting `gboolean` on it's own line makes it seem like it returns a `gboolean` when in reality it returns a function that takes zero arguments and returns a function pointer that will return a gboolean w/ 3 arguments.

I swear sometimes the only way to make C make sense is to have written a `type-specifier` parser :smile:

Unfortunately that’s not permissible, as `gpoll.h` needs to work on platforms which don’t have a `poll.h`.

AIX: build failure due to pollfd structure change

note.body:
Rootcause:

reqevents and rtnevents members has been defined in AIX poll.h system file. 

```
#define events  reqevents               /* SVR3,4 pollfd member name    */
#define revents rtnevents               /* SVR3,4 pollfd member name    */
```

**Solution 1:**

it seems the order how gpoll.h is included in the gmain.c file, is causing this issue.
gmain.c -> glib-unix.h -> glib.h -> giochannel.h -> gmain.h -> gpoll.h 
but poll.h is added after glib-unix.h in gmain.c.

And all further entry of events/revents in gmain.c is replaced by reqevents/rtnevents. But this struct member is not present in GPollFD. 

if community agrees , then can we include poll.h  before glib-unix.h

**Solution 2:**

Include poll.h file in glib/gpoll.h file 

Please let me know for which solution shall i raise PR.

note.body:
Hi @creiter,

I'm actually all for removing the VS2017 items, when no more CI jobs are using it (I think GTK is also using it as well, currently), as:

* Building GTK with debug code enabled requires `/Zc:preprocessor`, which only VS2019 16.8.x+ or later provides. I think I should open an MR at GTK to shift to building with VS2019 there as well.
* Introspection builds are working better in VS2019+ than VS2017, especially in the preprocessor department (there are bugs related to this one in HarfBuzz, Graphene and so)
* ARM64 support is better in VS2019+ than VS2017, as ARM64 support was added to VS2017 more like an afterthought.

My take on this-as a result, I am currently building my UCRT-based Visual Studio builds of the GTK stack, along with many other items, with VS2019 instead of VS2015 since about 1.5-2 years ago.

With blessings, and cheers!

target_title: Warnings from Meson due to subtests with INHERIT_STDOUT with TAP version 14

note.body:
Meson does not know about subtests at all; if you specify `TAP version 14` and then actually send TAP14 data (for example, any indented line other than the YAML format that is in v13) then it complains. In any case the `# Subtest` preamble is optional (see "Bare Subtests").

Unfortunately, if I do any of the proposed changes it seems that the output from the subprocess is lost completely, even on failure. For example, if I remove `G_TEST_SUBPROCESS_INHERIT_STDOUT` I get

```
# child process (/test/subprocess [531035]) exit status: 1 (error)
# child process (/test/subprocess [531035]) stdout: ""
# child process (/test/subprocess [531035]) stderr: "**\nERROR:../mytest.c:14:my_test_subprocess: assertion failed (43 == 42): (43 == 42)\n"
```

  * Represents a file descriptor, which events to poll for, and which events
  * occurred.
  */
+#if defined _AIX && !defined __64BIT__
+#define events reqevents

+#endif  /* defined _AIX && !defined __64BIT__ */

 {

```

target_title: Warnings from Meson due to subtests with INHERIT_STDOUT with TAP version 14

note.body:
This is because of a combination of things, any one of which you could change to work around the issue:
 * Using `printf()` rather than `g_test_message()`, which means that the subprocess output goes through the subprocess stdout handling code in `wait_for_child()`, rather than being handled at the point of emission.
 * Specifying `G_TEST_SUBPROCESS_INHERIT_STDOUT` rather than `G_TEST_SUBPROCESS_DEFAULT`, which forces the subprocess output to be printed all the time, rather than just on failure.

The ultimate bug is either that GLib is not printing the subtest preamble (`# Subtest\n` from the `Subtest` generation on https://testanything.org/tap-version-14-specification.html#tap14-format), or that Meson is not parsing it. I have not investigated which.

glib: Don't require GLIB_DOMAIN to be a NUL-terminated string

note.body:
Yeah, this is hard to parse. Perhaps it would be simpler if you could keep the existing structure, but replace the `strstr()` calls with calls to a new helper function:
```c
void *
memmem_with_end_pointer (void   *haystack,
                         void   *haystack_end,
                         void   *needle,
                         size_t  needle_len)
{
  return memmem (haystack, haystack_end - haystack, needle, needle_len);
}
```

Then you should be able to pre-calculate `haystack_end` outside the loop, avoid having to re-calculate a `haystack_len` within the loop, and hence call `memmem_with_end_pointer()` basically exactly the same way that `strstr()` is currently called.

note.body:
Documentation of g_log_structured() says:

```
  * Note that keys that expect UTF-8 strings (specifically `"MESSAGE"` and
  * `"GLIB_DOMAIN"`) must be passed as nul-terminated UTF-8 strings until GLib
  * version 2.74.1 because the default log handler did not consider the length of
  * the `GLogField`. Starting with GLib 2.74.1 this is fixed and
  * non-nul-terminated UTF-8 strings can be passed with their correct length.
```

So this has just never been true, right? It would not have worked correctly prior to your fix here? Should we update the version number in the documentation?

note.body:
Actually this part maybe (probably?) caused by an earlier build as root.
```
40/276 glib:glib / mappedfile                                   FAIL              0.09s   killed by signal 6 SIGABRT
>>> G_TEST_BUILDDIR=/home/test-glib2/rpmbuild/BUILD/glib-2.68.1/aarch64-xxx-linux-gnu/glib/tests G_TEST_SRCDIR=/home/test-glib2/rpmbuild/BUILD/glib-2.68.1/glib/tests MALLOC_PERTURB_=127 MALLOC_CHECK_=2 G_DEBUG=gc-friendly /home/test-glib2/rpmbuild/BUILD/glib-2.68.1/aarch64-xxx-linux-gnu/glib/tests/mappedfile
```
If a root build creates a file like `/tmp/glib-test-4096-random-bytes`, then a consecutive userspace build may have permission problems, when it also tries to create it.

target_title: trash is not working on mounted btrfs subvol (internal system mounts message)

note.body:
The fix is to add `x-gvfs-trash` to the subvolume mount options following https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs/-/merge_requests/222.

Edit: more context:
```sh
$ sudo mount -o subvol=test1,x-gvfs-trash /dev/sda1 /mnt/test1
$ touch /mnt/test1/file.txt
$ gio trash /mnt/test1/file.txt
$ tree /mnt/test1/.Trash-1000
/mnt/test1/.Trash-1000
├── files
│   └── file.txt
└── info
    └── file.txt.trashinfo
```

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
> Hm, so is valgrind wrong to add [suppressions like this](https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=484002) then?

I haven't dug into it, so I am not sure -- it depends on how the out-of-bounds memory access is done: if it is done in inline assembly, and the potentially OOB bytes are masked off before returning the value into C, then this is fine. But doing the access from C, including with an intrinsic, risks trouble.

Sadly, I don't think C offers a way to tell the compiler "this access may be OOB, I promise it won't page-fault though so please just let me do that". That's just a missing feature in the language that everyone has to work around until it gets added. :(

> Can we construct a scenario where this can actually happen to make it a little easier to analyze?

Sorry, I am mostly knowledgeable in reasoning about what compilers are allowed to do, and have a rough idea of what they will do in practice *in principle*, when the stars align. It is much harder to write an exploit than to find a bug, and it requires very particular skills to coerce the compiler to apply the right optimizations in the right order to make a nice example. Sadly, when code is sufficiently widely used and inlined into other codebases, the stars might align somewhere in production where nobody expects it.

In the code I work on, we don't accept even such potential problems, and systematically avoid UB. That's why I noticed this issue and left my comment. (That code is written in Rust, but this particular issue around not having a reliable way to do OOB reads plagues both C and Rust.) Other codebases can of course have their own rules, as long as that is a conscious decision and not just an accident. :)

Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
`--partial-loads-ok=yes` seems to be the valgrind equivalent of suppressing this (globally)? From what I read it seems like it needs to be a naturally aligned load (so `*(int*)ptr` is okay, but `(int *)[3]` would still trigger warnings).

That probably still requires that the implementation here to have actually swapped those shifts into the aligned loads though.

> We could use `#pragma GCC optimize ("O0")` and hope that is enough to prevent the compiler from reordering things?

I don't think you'll get the shifts optimized then.

> For instance, LLVM does this when they argue that a 4-byte read cannot possibly alias with an object that has a size of 3 or fewer bytes -- LLVM will happily reorder memory accesses assuming such non-aliasing.

Can we construct a scenario where this can actually happen to make it a little easier to analyze?

```c
static gboolean
something (char *a, char *b_alias_of_a_tail)
{
  *b_alias_of_a_tail = 0;
  return g_utf8_validate (a, -1, NULL);
}
```

or do you mean something different? I would expect that since everything here is `1` that the aliasing shouldn't matter.

target_title: gdate: Fix minor typo in documentation comment
Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
There’s a relevant talk about how valgrind prefers to handle optimised SSE variants of functions here: https://archive.fosdem.org/2015/schedule/event/valgrind_easy_hack/attachments/slides/731/export/events/attachments/valgrind_easy_hack/slides/731/valgrind_easy_hacks.html

Perhaps a good place to look to find the right tradeoff between avoiding undefined behaviour where it matters, and using SSE instructions for performance, would be glibc’s implementations of various string functions (like `strlen()`). Those are optimised using SSE, but we can be pretty sure they’re still correct when compiled by various compilers, and don’t fall foul of undefined behaviour optimisations.

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
Hm, so is valgrind wrong to add [suppressions like this](https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=484002) then?

[Two weeks ago](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/merge_requests/4302#note_2231660) I was arguing that we should be defensive and write code according to what the language guarantees rather than what happens to work on current hardware. But in that case, serious performance issues were unlikely. In this case, it seems like this out of bounds read makes a pretty significant performance improvement.

We could use `#pragma GCC optimize ("O0")` and hope that is enough to prevent the compiler from reordering things?

Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
FWIW this is not just a valgrind fluke. Doing out-of-bounds reads is unambiguously Undefined Behavior in C and compilers are permitted to exploit that for optimizations. For instance, LLVM does this when they argue that a 4-byte read cannot possibly alias with an object that has a size of 3 or fewer bytes -- LLVM will happily reorder memory accesses assuming such non-aliasing. You can of course choose to hope that such an optimization won't affect this code, but that's a very fragile assumption.

Computers might work in cachelines, but C does not.

**Before**:

```asm
000000000007a230 <g_utf8_validate>:
   7a230:       55                      push   %rbp
   7a231:       48 89 e5                mov    %rsp,%rbp
   7a234:       53                      push   %rbx
   7a235:       48 89 d3                mov    %rdx,%rbx
   7a238:       48 83 ec 18             sub    $0x18,%rsp
   7a23c:       48 89 7d e8             mov    %rdi,-0x18(%rbp)
   7a240:       48 85 f6                test   %rsi,%rsi
   7a243:       79 2b                   jns    7a270 <g_utf8_validate+0x40>
   7a245:       48 8d 7d e8             lea    -0x18(%rbp),%rdi
   7a249:       31 f6                   xor    %esi,%esi
   7a24b:       e8 50 e1 ff ff          call   783a0 <utf8_verify>
   7a250:       48 8b 45 e8             mov    -0x18(%rbp),%rax
   7a254:       48 85 db                test   %rbx,%rbx
   7a257:       74 03                   je     7a25c <g_utf8_validate+0x2c>
   7a259:       48 89 03                mov    %rax,(%rbx)
   7a25c:       80 38 00                cmpb   $0x0,(%rax)
   7a25f:       48 8b 5d f8             mov    -0x8(%rbp),%rbx
   7a263:       c9                      leave
   7a264:       0f 94 c0                sete   %al
   7a267:       0f b6 c0                movzbl %al,%eax
   7a26a:       c3                      ret
   7a26b:       0f 1f 44 00 00          nopl   0x0(%rax,%rax,1)
   7a270:       e8 7b ff ff ff          call   7a1f0 <g_utf8_validate_len>
   7a275:       48 8b 5d f8             mov    -0x8(%rbp),%rbx
   7a279:       c9                      leave
   7a27a:       c3                      ret
   7a27b:       0f 1f 44 00 00          nopl   0x0(%rax,%rax,1)
```

**After**:

```asm
000000000007a230 <g_utf8_validate>:
   7a230:       55                      push   %rbp
   7a231:       48 89 e5                mov    %rsp,%rbp

   7a252:       00 
   7a253:       48 8d 45 c0             lea    -0x40(%rbp),%rax
   7a257:       31 d2                   xor    %edx,%edx
   7a259:       48 c7 45 c8 00 00 00    movq   $0x0,-0x38(%rbp)
   7a260:       00 
   7a261:       48 c7 45 d0 00 00 00    movq   $0x0,-0x30(%rbp)
   7a268:       00 
   7a269:       48 c7 45 d8 00 00 00    movq   $0x0,-0x28(%rbp)
   7a270:       00

   7a291:       48 87 db                xchg   %rbx,%rbx
   7a294:       48 89 55 b8             mov    %rdx,-0x48(%rbp)
   7a298:       48 8b 45 b8             mov    -0x48(%rbp),%rax
   7a29c:       85 c0                   test   %eax,%eax
   7a29e:       75 30                   jne    7a2d0 <g_utf8_validate+0xa0>
   7a2a0:       48 8d 7d a8             lea    -0x58(%rbp),%rdi
   7a2a4:       31 f6                   xor    %esi,%esi
   7a2a6:       e8 f5 e0 ff ff          call   783a0 <utf8_verify>

   7a2af:       48 85 db                test   %rbx,%rbx

   7a2d7:       e8 d4 70 f8 ff          call   13b0 <strlen@plt>

   7a2e2:       48 89 c6                mov    %rax,%rsi
   7a2e5:       e8 06 ff ff ff          call   7a1f0 <g_utf8_validate_len>
   7a2ea:       48 83 c4 50             add    $0x50,%rsp
   7a2ee:       5b                      pop    %rbx
   7a2ef:       41 5c                   pop    %r12
   7a2f1:       5d                      pop    %rbp
   7a2f2:       c3                      ret
   7a2f3:       0f 1f 44 00 00          nopl   0x0(%rax,%rax,1)
   7a2f8:       e8 f3 fe ff ff          call   7a1f0 <g_utf8_validate_len>
   7a2fd:       48 83 c4 50             add    $0x50,%rsp
   7a301:       5b                      pop    %rbx
   7a302:       41 5c                   pop    %r12
   7a304:       5d                      pop    %rbp
   7a305:       c3                      ret
   7a306:       66 2e 0f 1f 84 00 00    cs nopw 0x0(%rax,%rax,1)
   7a30d:       00 00 00 
```

Patch used:

```patch
diff --git a/glib/gutf8.c b/glib/gutf8.c
index f54a0a2be..f172f6641 100644
--- a/glib/gutf8.c
+++ b/glib/gutf8.c
@@ -40,6 +40,7 @@
 #include "gtypes.h"
 #include "gthread.h"
 #include "glibintl.h"
+#include "gvalgrind.h"
 
 #define UTF8_COMPUTE(Char, Mask, Len)                                        \
   if (Char < 128)                                                            \
@@ -1859,6 +1860,9 @@ g_utf8_validate (const char   *str,
   if (max_len >= 0)
     return g_utf8_validate_len (str, max_len, end);
 
+  if G_UNLIKELY (RUNNING_ON_VALGRIND)
+    return g_utf8_validate_len (str, strlen (str), end);
+
   utf8_verify (&str, NULL);
 
   if (end != NULL)

```

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
Adding a runtime branch for this would be easiest as:

```c
if (valgrind_enabled)
  return g_utf8_validate_len (str, strlen(str), end);
```

but I'd really like to avoid that branch if possible.

Can we treat valgrind as an architecture variant so the linker can place this variant in the PLT at linker-load time?

target_title: Incorrect Documentation for g_unix_mount_get_mount_path Return Value Ownership

note.body:
> However, this contradicts the source code. According to the code, the returned string is owned by the GUnixMountEntry itself, not by the called function, and therefore should not be freed by the caller.

Just as a side note: From my understanding the description is not 100% accurate but it does **not** imply that you are supposed to free the data. As the return value is owned “by the _called_ function” a free from the _caller_ would lead to a double fee bug.

See e.g. the content of the Gir file for this function: `<return-value transfer-ownership="none"> ` It explicitly defines that no ownership is transferred.

If a caller is supposed to free the data, the documentation would read something along the lines: “The caller of the function takes ownership of the data, and is responsible for freeing it.”

note.body: You can use valgrind.h to pretty easily take a different path at runtime than at compile time (at the cost that, yes, it's a different path and the normal path is no longer being tested). That's already demonstrated in several parts of glib (gvalgrind.h). In contrast, a valgrind suppression file is not useful because developers will not use it.

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
> There might be a hint which can be passed to asan (which is what oss-fuzz uses internally) and/or valgrind to tell them about it.

https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizer#turning-off-instrumentation and valgrind suppression files

That means we’re going to lose all asan error reporting for `g_utf8_validate()`, which is quite a big risk.

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
> As long as it never actually uses the data past the `\0` in the result, what is the issue with reading past the `\0` so long as it's part of a word?

Yes, that’s what I think.

> My point here seems like this is something incorrect in oss-fuzz/valgrind worth fixing, particularly beacuse I doubt this is the only place doing it. I did think about this while writing it and (I guess wrongly) assumed they knew how to deal with this sort of optimization.

I’m not sure they can know that the error is a false positive: they know the heap allocation extents, and the read extents, and error when the latter is not a subset of the former. In most situations, that’s going to be a true positive. Code should really be limiting its reads to the heap allocation extents (even if the full word is actually loaded into the register under the hood).

There might be a hint which can be passed to asan (which is what oss-fuzz uses internally) and/or valgrind to tell them about it.

target_title: Heap buffer overflow read in utf8_verify_ascii()

note.body:
As long as it never actually uses the data past the `\0` in the result, what is the issue with reading past the `\0` so long as it's part of a word?

Computers work in cachelines, and the data is part of the cacheline. It can be loaded into the register anyway.

My point here seems like this is something incorrect in oss-fuzz/valgrind worth fixing, particularly beacuse I doubt this is the only place doing it. I did think about this while writing it and (I guess wrongly) assumed they knew how to deal with this sort of optimization.

note.body:
Thank you for your reply and explaining! It's very clear!

Based on your feedback, here’s my understanding of the proper fix:

```c
GIO_DEPRECATED_IN_2_82_FOR(g_unix_mount_entry_get_mount_path)
const char *   g_unix_mount_get_mount_path          (GUnixMountEntry    *mount_entry);

GIO_AVAILABLE_IN_2_82
const char *   g_unix_mount_entry_get_mount_path    (GUnixMountEntry    *mount_entry);
```

Could it be a merge request?

target_title: Incorrect Documentation for g_unix_mount_get_mount_path Return Value Ownership

note.body:
> 1. which version of GLib are you using?
> 2.81.0

This is a development snapshot released in June 2024; you either want to use GLib 2.80.5 (the last old stable release of the 2.80 cycle) or GLib 2.82.1 (the latest stable release).

> According to the code, the returned string is owned by the GUnixMountEntry itself, not by the called function, and therefore should not be freed by the caller.

The documentation is generated from the introspection data.

This issue is the result of the introspection data recognising `g_unix_mount_get_mount_path()` as a static function in the Gio namespace, and not as a method of the `GUnixMountEntry` object; if it were recognised as a method, the documentation would say: `The returned data is owned by the instance.`

The main issue is that the API is `g_unix_mount_*` but the instance is `GUnixMountEntry`, which confuses the introspection data generator. In theory, there's the `(method)` annotation for mismatching cases, but with the instance type having a different snake case prefix, the end result is that the method would end up being `GioUnix.MountEntry.unix_mount_get_mount_path()`.

The proper fix would be deprecating all the `g_unix_mount_*` API that takes a `GUnixMountEntry`, and replacing it with the equivalent `g_unix_mount_entry_*` API.

target_title: Incorrect Documentation for g_unix_mount_get_mount_path Return Value Ownership

Perhaps it would be fine, but there’s no pressing need to provide such a guarantee at the GLib level, so it’s not something I want to put any time into. target_title: Determine policy on 32-bit support

note.body:
> I think GLib needs to continue to support 32-bit systems for at least as long as Debian does

Even if Debian didn't exist or dropped support for i386, other distros would still want 32-bit GLib as a multilib second-class citizen like Arch's `lib32-glib2`, in order to support things like 32-bit Wine.

With my consultancy hat on, Steam also uses 32-bit GLib - it ships its own old version that it can use as a fallback, but it'll work better if it has access to a newer and more-bug-fixed version from the OS.

target_title: Determine policy on 32-bit support

note.body:
> In particular [Debian will continue to support 32-bit](https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel-announce/2023/12/msg00003.html) installations for at least the next few years, _but_ they are dropping 32-bit kernel support. So you will be able to run 32-bit Debian in a container or chroot, but not on bare metal.

To clarify this, Debian is dropping 32-bit kernels **on x86**. I believe the `armel` and `armhf` ports (32-bit ARMv5 EABI softfloat, and 32-bit ARMv7 EABI hardfloat, respectively) continue to have kernels available, although debian-installer is dropping support for new installations of `armel`.

In fact the main use-case for i386 on Debian is not a container, a chroot, or upgrading an existing installation, but instead, installing its packages onto an x86_64 system to provide the ability to run legacy 32-bit binaries (in practice mainly games), either native Linux binaries directly or Windows binaries via 32-bit Wine. In Debian this is done via "multiarch" (libraries in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu vs. /usr/lib/i386-linux-gnu) whereas most other distributions like Fedora and Arch use "multilib" (/usr/lib64 vs. /usr/lib, or /usr/lib vs. /usr/lib32), but the idea is the same.

Pragmatically, if we want to support 32-bit anything, then i386 on Linux is going to be the easiest way to smoke-test it - we can run an i386 Docker container on the x86_64 CI workers that GNOME already has. That will detect any regressions that are only word-size-dependent and not specific to one architecture or OS, like expecting `gsize` to be the same size as `goffset`.

> A 32bit CI is useful to catch issues with calling conventions (\__cdecl vs \__stdcall) or alignment mismatches

For Windows-specific issues like `__cdecl` vs. `__stdcall`, only 32-bit *Windows* CI can detect these.

For alignment and type-size mismatches, 32-bit Linux CI will often be enough (32-bit Windows and Linux are both "ILP32", with 32-bit int, long and pointers).

target_title: CI: Use Visual Studio 2019 for the MSVC CI

note.body:
```suggestion:-0+0
  extends: .only-schedules-or-manual
```

I think this should run weekly, rather than on every merge request. The MSVC builds are already the slowest part of running a CI pipeline (I think due to being serialised on a small number of runners), and adding another job into that critical path is going to slow things down further. We shouldn’t regress on 32-bit MSVC any more than we regress on 32-bit builds in general (already tested in another job) or MSVC in general (already tested via the 64-bit MSVC jobs), so I think checking for 32-bit MSVC regressions weekly should be sufficient.

My solution here has another critical problem:

> The complicating factor in `GTask` was that the thread can continue to use the task data and source object after calling its return functions. So to do this with any correctness, you need to delay the result until after the callback completes.

I haven't accounted for this possibility. See Christian's full comment [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/1346#note_2231816) for more details.

target_title: Discussion: utf8 validation optimization

note.body:
```sh
christian@fedora:~$ ./test-original ~/Projects/sandbox/lorem.txt 
703 MB/s
christian@fedora:~$ jhbuild shell 
[christian@fedora:~]$ ./test-original ~/Projects/sandbox/lorem.txt 
10173 MB/s
```

This test is on an x86_64 Xeon 4214 and it went about 15x faster, so pretty much what was expected.

On aarch64 (Asahi M2 pro) we go from `2,200` to `26,700` for a 12x speedup.

Test case was the same as c-utf8 bencharmk-ascii but using `g_utf8_validate()` w/ `>= length`.

Will update MR soon.

target_title: Discussion: utf8 validation optimization

note.body: As a quick followup, I can also say that we do in fact get the same performance with `if (byte >= lower && byte <= upper)` so that is a fine cleanup too.

target_title: Discussion: utf8 validation optimization

note.body:
If I force disable inlining I can compare the `__builtin_assume_aligned(8)` and `__attribute__((aligned(8)))` cases.

In both cases, we get:

```
0000000000401490 <load_word>:
  401490:       48 8b 04 37             mov    (%rdi,%rsi,1),%rax
  401494:       c3                      ret
  401495:       66 66 2e 0f 1f 84 00    data16 cs nopw 0x0(%rax,%rax,1)
  40149c:       00 00 00 00 
```

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/cpp/align-cpp?view=msvc-170 says you can use the `__declspec(align(n))` on declarators which include `auto` variables in functions. So there is a chance we can make it work there too.

note.body:
> and I guess create a `G_GNUC_ASSUME_ALIGNED(8)` attribute or something like that which works on GCC/Clang?

No need to go to those lengths: from a maintenance point of view, I’d be happy with just tightening the `#if GCC or Clang` check to around the use of `__builtin_assume_aligned()`, and letting other compilers just had the definition of `m` without `__builtin_assume_aligned()`. They probably won’t have terrible performance.

We don’t need to go to the lengths of defining a new public `G_GNUC_ASSUME_ALIGNED` macro; this can all remain internal.

target_title: Discussion: utf8 validation optimization

note.body:
The other bit is the `__builtin_assume_aligned()` so the compiler knows it can convert the shift and mask operations into a simd instruction.

We could just use that and let compilers which can't optimize it be slower, it's unlikely worse than what we have now.

That said, for small strings I doubt you'd see too much difference. But for the longer strings you'll see the speedup mentioned above. The "(trivial)" example there is basically a copy of GLib's implementation (via systemd) put into the c-utf8 code-base.

target_title: Determine policy on 32-bit support

note.body:
> So we can drop 32 Windows jobs in GLib?

I would prefer to keep at least one kind of 32-bit builder in the upstream GLib CI pipeline in order to prevent 32-bit regressions from landing and getting into downstreams (even if only on the `main` branch). It’s a lot cheaper to fix a regression in the MR which causes it, rather than in a follow-up MR days or weeks later when the problem finally gets caught somewhere.

target_title: mainloop Unix FD test intermittently fails on Hurd

note.body:
> I would certainly expect that after you complete a `write ()` on a pipe successfully, a `poll ()` from the same thread will immediately return, indicating the other end of the pipe as readable (assuming nobody else drained the pipe in the meantime). In particular this should be true with poll timeout set to 0.

That won’t be true if a higher priority `GSource` on the `GMainContext` becomes ready: it will be dispatched on the next main context iteration, and `poll()` might not even be called. I don’t know if that’s what’s happening here, but it’s an illustration of how the guarantees provided by `GMainContext` don’t necessarily directly map to the libc or kernel guarantees.
